values:
Back after a two-year hiatus...is anybody still friended to this journal? Today Tristan sent me some old travelogues from his bike trip, and I got to thinking about Europe journals... picking up where I left of in 2007, here's Scotland:

Thursday, May 27/04
LOCHRANZA HOSTEl, ARRAN, SCOTLAND
It's 3pm and the hostel is deserted, which is no great surprise as the weather is absolutely fantastic, as it has been since we arrived in Great Britain. Katy is upstairs writing in her journal because (silly child) she says she can only write properly lying down. I was going to write a long, drawn-out email to Tyler (I'm overdue), but reception is closed until 5pm (so I can't buy an Internet voucher), so instead I'm sitting out here in the glorious sun (like a clever child) writing in my journal as well, and drinking a cup (read: pot) of tea. I am totally addicted to tea!

So, we are on the Isle of Arran, a beautiful island in the southwest of Scotland. It's known as "Scotland in Miniature", and for good reason: in the 3-hour drive around the island, I have seen landscaped reminiscent of Northern Ontario, New Brunswick, Kluane National Park (Yukon), the Top of the World Highway (Yukon/Alaska), the Big Island (Hawaii), Galiano Island, Nanaimo, and ourvery own Pacific Northwest, jst to name a few. It's absolutely stunning - the only real difference is that I've never seen sheep roaming wild about the countryside in any of those places.

We got here on Tuesday night, after a long but serendipitously well-connected voyage from Crewe (Ray and Judy's) via Glasgow. Yesterday we took buses almost all the way around the isle, including the inland sections (the Island is very mountainous, so most of the villages are on the coast). We meant to travel to Brodick first (about 40 min trip), it being the location of the only ATMs on the island and us down to 13pounds cash (Caitlin the Dumbass having misplaced the other 20-pound note (not a ood thing to lose - that's the equivalent of fifty Canadian dollars!), but unfortunately we missed our stop, not realizing that on school mornings that bus runs all the way to the highschool in Lmlash. So, wound up in Lamlash, with the next bus in either direction moer than an hour's wait. The thing you have to understand about Arran, too, is that when I use the term "village", I mean VILLAGE. We're talking a cluster of 20-odd houses with, if you're lucky, a corner store (not that there are any corners, there being only one street), and a post office. Not the most enthralling place to be stuck for an hour and a half. Pretty, but no entertainment value. Once we finally escaped (deciding to continue forwards, since we'd already passed Brodick anyhow), we went to Whiting Bay (again pretty, again small, again an hour's wait), and walked along the beach - BLAH, SO DON'T WANT TO WRITE! - and then FINALLY arrived in Blackwaterfoot, hours after we left the hostel. Went (this was the original point) to Machrie Moor standing stones, which were much more like actual standing stones than the ones at Carnac - certainly differently impressive. What do you say about standing stones? they were big, and on end. Lol. I mean, really, you just have to see them in order to feel "the full weight of hstory", etc etc.

Man, I really need a new journal... Gawd, I am SO distractable today...it just feels like there's sooo much left to write about, and really there isn't...
Today was a horrible day from the outset (don't worry, though, it ends happily). We had planned to go on a hike from Whiting Bay, which led to the "Giant's Grav" and Glenashborough Falls, and (in a dramatic contraditiction of Murphy's Law - or so we thought) the sky was amazingly clear when we woke up, and the air was pleasantly warm with a light, cool breeze - perfect weather for a hike. At this point, of course, being the cynics we pretend we are, we should have Suspected Something. We did not, and this was our downfall.

(1) We were going to phone Martina, and the phone card wouldn't work; (2) Katy got her period; (3) our soft-boiled eggs hard-boiled; (4) our kiwis were too unripe to eat; (5) we had a mad bus panis; (6) Katy developed horrendous cramps; (7) we lost a pound somewhere on the street; (8) upon entering the bus, we realized we had forgotten the extra camera battery; (9) and, upon further investigation, the camera itself; (10) in the exposed and unprotected kitchen cubbyhole; (11) overnight!... (12) And as we got of the bus in Whiting Bay, I forgot my blue cardigan on the seat, realizing it seconds too late... and (13) Katy's cramps became crippling.

At about this point, we decided that the piling of crises had gone far enough, and we should split up.

Friday, May 29th, 2004
NEWTON STEWART, MINNIGAFF HOSTEL
Sorry about that...I got distracted, and then Katy came downstairs and started bitching about the sun, so the entry got aborted rather suddenly...but that's okay, I was getting bored with writing it anyhow, and its never a good idea to write when you're bored or tired, cause the writing always suffers for it. Anyway. So (to take a brief interlude from the previous and already interrupted subject) now we are in Newton Stewart (technically Minigaff, but it's the same thing essentially), staying at another SYHA Hostel with the most adorable owners and an incredibly friendly family feel. IT started raining this morning as we left Arran, and the weather's still looking fairly gloomy, but I figure after 2 weeks of beautiful weather we pretty much deserve it . The journey from Arran to NS took entirely too long (over 10 hours!!) because we had to take a rather circuitous route involvign backtracking nearly to Glasgow from Ardrossan (the mainland pier) and then changing trains and waiting for busses in various small towns, including a three-hour wait in Ayr and an hour's wait in Stranraer. When we finally got to NS, we realized we had no idea where the hostel was otehr than a vague suspicion that it was across the bridge in Minnigaff (hence the name)...however, we eventually found a friendly policeman, and he pointed us in the right direction, and here we are.

SO. Back to the crises of yesterday...briefly, we solved them thus:
Katy and I, as I said, decided to go our separate ways. She would make her painful way back to the Hostel, there to write in her journal, find out what she could about Lost and Found items on the busses, organize our stuff, and just generally spend as much time in a fetal position as is possible for a post-natal human being, while I, who was not in pain and really really wanted to do this hike, would go it alone and return to the hostel following my adventure. Seemed like a good solution, so we divvied up the food, argued over possession of the watch (it wasn't actually much of an argument truth be told - I said, "Oh no, we only have one watch," and she took it off and handed it to me, but stil...), and separated.

And I must say I think I definitely got the better end of this deal, although Katy may tell you differently. The hike really was fabulous...the landscape actually reminded me very much of home, which was nice (I couldn't decide whetehr it was more like Terrace Mountain or the walk to Gruchy's Beach), adn as I have said the weather was amazing. It was also really nice just to be finally actually moving and exerting myself, and to be able to move at my own pace - something I don't get to do very often since everybody always wants either to go slower or faster than I do; I've never really hiked on my own before, unless you count the Cottage and the area around Terrace. It was also a lot less dangerous than any walking a person might want to do around our area, since there are no bears or other dangerous wildlife and there were just the right number of people on the path - enough that you run into them every ten minutes or so so you dont' get worried about being All Alone In The Woods, but not so many that it ruins your illusions of solitude. The walk to the Giant's Graves only took about 15 minutes, although there were 330 steps (the guidbook only advertized 26...grr! I hate step!), and it was pretty, but unspectactular. The forest glade there were set in was very nice, and I would have taken pictures if I'd had the camera, cause the "graves" tehmselves (massive stone blocks forming inexplicable grave-shaped depressions in the ground) were quite interesting, but I'm not entirely sure that everyone would consider it to be worth the fuss.

The falls, however (I think, upon further consideration, that the name was Glenashdale) were quite lovely, adn I think anyone would agree. I mean, the thing about waterfalls is that they tend to look a lot like waterfalls (wow, deep), but they were very nice, and I just couldn't (and subsequently didn't) resist clambering around on the rocks at the top, and getting even more sunburnt. The patches of clearcutting did not add to the view particularly, but the various random and inexplicable bits of old stone houses, walls, and forts [that] you kep tstumbling over int he most unexpected places certainly did. Confused one old couple quite a bit by passing them about four times in a row...they simply couldn't figure out how I kept winding up behind them again, but it was because I repreatedly got sidetracked and wandered off the main trail to explore...the more extreme of these incidents was actually after the forest path had reemerged onto a road leading back down into town (Whiting Bay), when I took off up some unfenced meadows into the hills - that particular sidetrack took about half an hour, but the view of the bay from the top was definitely worth it! Singing of "The Hills are Alive With the Sound of Music" was perhaps undertaken at this juncture.

When I finally got down to the main road and caught a bus back to Brodick Pier to transfer to a bus for the hostel, I found Katy still there, sitting and waiting at the pier! Turns out that after she separated from me and caught a bus to Brodick that morning, she had found that the next bus to Lochranza didn't actually leave until 2:30...by which time I had caught up with her! In the interim she bought a ridiculously-cute little notebook and the blueberry-scented gell pen I was writing with yesterday from the TIC (Tourist Information Centre) at the pier, and had spent the day doodling and writing note to Martina. This is why I say I got the better end of the deal - I got to go on a wonderful hike and see things I will maybe never have the chance to see again, and she got a blueberry-flavoured pen and a sunburn (zeugma?).

It is, by the way, a testament both to the smallness of that island and the friendliness of its people that I did get my cardigan back after all. There are only about five bus drivers total, and they switch buses every so often so you get to know all of them in the course of a day... Katy talked at length to the driver who brought her to Brodick, and between him and the driver of the bus I left it on, the cardigan arrived at the pier about the same time I did, and made it back into my hands just when I thought it had gone forever. In fact, a lady came up to Katy on that bus and asked if 'her friend had left her sweater on the bus for Whiting Bay'. Small world - no; small island. There was this couple from Birmingham, for example, who were staying at the Lochranza Hostel with us, and we must have bumped into them five different times in various places on the island. Likewise with ayoungish fellow who checked into the hostel the same night we did, whom we ran into the next day in Blackwaterfoot of all places. It was quite funny.

Incidentally, the camer (forgtooen about that, had you?) survived its ordeal (god bless honest/incurious backpackers!) and we emailed Tuna...
Lol.. will talk about the awful monopoly game another time - need sleep now. Cannot wait to get to Wigtown as my need for a new journal grows increasingly desperate...
Love Caitlin.

Saturday, May 29, 2004
A few more people staying our room tonight, but thankfully they aren't early risers and don't need the lights out right away, so I'll fill in a little bit more before going to bed.
...Hmm, or not, since Katy has just talked my ear off for the past 25 minutes and now our roommates are back...and I mean, really, after all this time what can we possily have to talke about? Lol, yep, you guessed it...boys. *L* Not THE boys, this time, but Paul, and Uzzie, and nostalgia...anyway, I'll try to catch up tomorrow. *sigh* I'm not even tired...hate dorms. Lol. G'night!
Love Caitlin

Sunday, May 30/04
So let's try this again, shall we? I've had to tear myself away from my book (well, books, actually - I'm currently in the middle of Captain Corelli's Mandolin, Soul Music ( a Discworld novel), and Shakespeare's Twelfth Night  which is actually a bit dull, truth be told...I have to say that I generally like his tragedy etter than his comedy - and often think if funnier, besides, lol. They're all interesting but not totally gripping books, so I've been switching off-and-on between them...this being just one of the perils encountered in a town full of second-hand bookshops...oops, that was a rather longer aside than strictly necessary, considering I was going to tlak about all this stuff anyway...lol) in order to write, and furthermore it's becoming almost impossible to see the lines of the book in this waning light (yes I'm aware that I could simply go and turn on the lisghts, but I twisted my ankle quite badly this afternon and eyesight is just not worth climbing down the ladder of a bunkbed to save...), so I'll brook no complaints if I wander off topic during this entry - I've earned it.!

So, to catch up, as usual... Yesterday, for practically the first time since we came to Britain, it rained. (I say practically because it did *technically* rain - torrentially - for about half an hour the day we went to Chester; however, considering the weather we'd been warned to expect in Britain and considering that we spend the majority of that half hour in a toy shop anyhow, we can't really complain). We started out the morning be heading to Castle Douglas, which is a town (not a castle) about an hour's bus ride from Newton Stewart that was hosting a festival that day that the manager here (Richard, by name recommended to us. Food is to Castle Douglas what books are to Wigtown (yes, literally - it's called "Scotland's National Foodtown") and it was a food festival. Unfortunately the festival proper wasn't scheduled to start until 11am and we got there at 9, with the result that we spend a couple of rainy hours in what is actually a fairly dreary little town, ate breakfast at a little cafe (genuine "fruit" - read: raisin - scones and mochas with foam: 6 pounds), and then left at five past 11, just before the festivities actually started. This turned out to be a mistake, as the weather cleared about an hour later, and fold who stayed said it was great fun. Tant pis: we went to Wigtown.

Wigtown is awesome. How could a town known for its second-hand bookshops NOT be awesome? We decided, in an effort to restrain ourselves, that we should hold off buying anything until we had checked out all fo the bookstores in the town and compared prices - I realize that this ruins the spontaneity of the venture somewhat, but we are practically Starving Students, after all. Unfortunately, the Clever Plan backfired somewhat, since by the time we got to the last shop (Transformer, nearly two miles out of town as it turns out, but boasting the largest collection of secondhand sci-fi and fantasy n the UK - who could pass it up?) we were practically slavering...plust the lady who runs it was completely marellous (her name was Carol, before I forget, and she was about 45 years old with bright pink hair...) and the collection of books, stacked in heaps in boxes, staircases, and on the floor where they spilled off the shelves, was trulye awe-inspiring. ...We wound up spending nearly 20 pounds there, which is about fifty Canadian dollars... however, some of those were books I've been searching for for a long time, such as Songmaster and a replacement copy of Macroscope. Anyway. We felt justified.

Today we got a ride to the Isle of Whithorn with Richard (the hostel manager, ou remember) and his wife, Primrose. It was extremely friendly of them - they were headed there anyway for a Sunday 'tea' of some sort, and took us by several little towns on the way ... buses are great things and I appreciate their services, but it's quite wonderful to be shown around a place by the people who know and love it. They also took us to their "typical Scottish house" in Whithorn, which was completely stunning. It's adjacent to the Bank of Scotland, and it used to be the bank manager's residence, apparently; beautiful wooden annisters and ten foot ceilings, it was wonderful. The attic room was especially neat, accessed by a tiny spiral staircase... it was really very nice of them to show us around. We spent the afternoon (the arly part of it at any rate) basking in the sun, which shone with renewed vigour after its day off, on the Isle of Whithorn, which is actualy a part of the peninsula now although it used to be an island. It is apparently the start of yet another pilgrimmage route (although we didn't see any shells this time), so we walked to the headland to look at St Ninian's Chapel, only to become confused as to whether it was in fact the collapsing old stone house or the whitewashed and oddly cuibcal lighthouse which personified the holy place... REgardless, however, the headland itself was beautiful, and a great spot for a picnic...

On the way back to the bus stop I twisted my ankle rather severely, and although it certainly isn't officially sprained (not nearly swollen enough), it is also not particularly pleasant to walk on, and I'm afraid I've been being a bit of a bab about it all evening...but that's okay, cause Katy's been complaining about her hip again, too, so we can be invalids together...
Hmm, I appear to be rather drastically running out of pages in this book...I looked for a replacement while we were in Wigtown, but I'm so spoiled aobut bindings now, and all they had were spiral-bound books with butterlies on them for far too much money (nearly as much as I spent on this one, if you will believe it), which I simply couldn't accept...however, in light of new circumstances which have recently come to light (ie the end of the book?) I may have to just swallow my pride and buy one, since any journal (almost) would be better than no journal at all...

Hmm, and I should like to fill all of this space, since it is after all here in front fo me, but what does one say when faced with such a void? So long, and thanks for all the fish. Gawd, another cliceh. Just when you thought you were free...
 
(Tyler, Tyler, Tyler).

Love, Caitlin.

Just a note: all Europe Trip posts will be Friends Only due to sensitive subject nature. That will continue to be true for a lot of entres post-Europe as well; so if you know me (or don't know me) and are interested in reading this stuff, let me know and I'll friend you. Thanks! Caitlin.

Friday, October 3rd/03

Ok. Even though it's really late, I have to get up tomorrow, and I'm very tired, I'm strung out and out of sorts, and I suspect that even though the act of writing takes up valuable sleeping time, the benefits gained from its therapeutic value will outweigh the detriments.
I shouldn't have ever considered working at a place that's open 24/7. It's stupid. Not only do I never have free nights (and therefore no times off which correspond with anyone else), but also, as someone with no seniority, I have to work holidays - which means, for example, that I'm working Thanksgiving Monday, and it also means I'll probably have to work Christmas - a prospect which is already upsetting me deeply.
It also means I never get enough sleep, cause I need to be up early enough to accomplish things before work, and it means that either I don't get ot hang out with people or else that I abuse myself in order to do it- cause I don't have weekends, and everyone else does.
*Self-pitying sigh*. I don't know why everything's bothering me so much this evening. I hate my life. I resent Katy's. I resent Katy, for not appreciating what she has. I miss regularity.
I miss Tyler.
I'm insanely attracted to Mark Biagioni. Again. Still. Why?!!

Caitlin.

Tuesday, Oct 7/03
I'm so paranoid and protective of this journal now, after what happened with the airlines this summer. I didn't mean to write tonight at all, but I looked ont he shelf for this book when I lay down, and it wasn't there. I knew where it was - it was in the backpack I took with me to Vancouver - but I had this sudden insane thought that perhaps I'd left it on the plane or in the hotel. Not that I could do anything about it at 2 o'clock on a Wednesday morning even if I had, but I had to check all the same. And it was there - obviously - and now I'm writing. And have just taken up twelve lines to say that - it's no wonder I fill this book so quickly.

I really needed to talk to Tyler tonight and he wasn't home. As I said when I emailed him, I suppose that's only fair; after all, I'm practically never here when he calls me. But I needed him so much tonight, and I'm not sure why. I think its partly having been in Vancouver - it's frustrating to be so near and so far.
Katy and I got served alcohol at the Earl's in Vancouver. This was a big thrill. We were with Mum, and they seated us in the bar and gave us Margaritas without even questioning. :p It was kinda cool, in a juvenile look-at-us-we're-big-kids-now kind of way! We were in Vancouver buying Europe supplies at MEC. Plans are progressing comfortably - we now have most of the required big-ticket items and our relatives in France (me) and England (Katy) have been contacted. We aren't planning to leave until April still, but it's nice to feel like we have things more or less under control. Now all we need is to suffer through the next six months - and to accumulate money - and for Katy to not have her passport application rejected - that process is so irritating! 
*Yawn* And I guess I also need to be sure to try to wrap up this journal by then as well so I don't have to lug it to Europe and back...only seventy-four pages left!
Goodnight, Kitty. :)

Thursday, October 9/03
Seems like all you've been getting lately is job complains and missing Tyler, but really that's all that's been going on. Bitched extensively in Livejournal today about job/music/life in general, so I really don't feel like complaining in here again - and besides, I feel significantly better having talked to Tyler; this afternoon, though, I was in really bad shape. Everything's random, and I feel constantly stressed and out of control. Suffice it to say, my life sucks.
Talking to Tyler really does help though. It's so nice to be loved. I miss my family - with my work schedule the way it is (mostly evenings) I never see them - I literally haven't eaten dinner here in over a week, closer to two. I hate it - at least Tyler give me some emotional stability, even if it is long distance.
Have worked 14 hours in the last 24, and am really, really, shaky tired. Don't really know why I started writing in the first place. What I need is sleep. And stability. And Tyler.
G'night, Kitty. :)

Thursday, October 16/03
**entry cut to maintain other people's confidentiality**

Friday, October 24/03
Fuck.  ...I start a lot of entries that way, don't I? But this is definitely one of those entries.
Oh, Kitty. Smack me. I've got butterflies in the pit of my stomach that have nobusiness being there.
I have a crush on Mark Biagioni. Did I just say those words? I did. I don't want to - except that I do, which is why I do, which is why I don't, even though that sentence would make no sense to anyone except possibly Katy. I have a crush on Mark Biagioni. That's all it is - a crush. I don't like him...particularly...I mean, I don't DISLIKE him, but he's shallow and sex-oriented and there's really no way around that. I have absolutely no interest in a relationship with him. I love Tyler. I mean that. If I'm seriously considering spending the rest of my life with him, trust me, I'm serious.
But Mark is here. And Mark is easy - that is, he requires no effort or emotional involvement, just casual flirting. Which in and of itself would be easy enough to ignore, except he flirts back. I wound up in a chair with him tonight watching a movie - not doing anything, just sitting. But at this point, physical contact of any sort feels pretty much like flirting.
And I really am physically attracted to him. Kind of like Jon Rife...sort of. He's ADORABLE. He's got wonderful hair. He's also two years younger than me (did I mention that?) Don't worry, if you're starting to. Nothing is going to happen, and again, I don't say that without meaning it. I know where my lines are, and we aren't near them, nor are we likely to get closer to them. Not only do we hardly ever see Mark, but I wouldn't let things get into a situation where it could go any further. It's very casual.
So why do I feel so bloody guilty?
A bewildered Caitlin.

Saturday, Oct 25/03 (Fall Back!)
Talked to Tyler this evening, and now feel much more how, as it were. Lol, essentially, I got the Official Go-Ahead on my flirtations with Mark. In as much as, yes, Tyler flirst with people too, yes, we're currently hundreds of miles apart, and if I have a crush on Kurt Biagioni's younger brother, that's ok by him.
Actually, he laughed at me! And it's funny how much better I feel, having told him that. It was meaningless before and it's meaningly now - but now it doesn't feel so...hidden, and Questionable.

Anyway. Need to sleep. Try to write tomorrow.
Happy daylight savings time. :)
Love Caitlin.

Saturday, Sept 20/03

Hey. Really tired, of course, but feel I should write, however briefly. I miss Tyler. Well, there's a new one. When you're bored sometime, try counting the number of entries since September of last year that he HASN'T been in. My guess is eight, and that's being generous. I've got a quote for you from a November livejournal which pertains to missing Tyler, but I'm not going to put it in right now. That would take WAY too long.
Blah. Worked eight hours today, work seven tomorrow. I really hate the way my life is right now. I know it's a job, and it's good money, and as menial labour goes it's not that bad, but...ehh. Blah. I just...I need structure, I need a schedule. I don't do well with this inconsistant 4-hours-there-and-5-here shit. It's really hard. Much as routine has its drags, it sure beats this. The irregularity puts me constantly on edge, and it's funny, cause when I'm actually at work I usually enjoy myself - it's when I'm off that I feel lost. I can see time slipping through my fingers, but I feel powerless to stop it. The time I have never seems long enough to DO anything in, and meanwhile it whittles away and I've practiced my piano twice and my voiice once and done no History at all. I need direction, and I need to schedule my time in order to accomplish things, and that's so tough to do when you don't know day to day what'll be asked of you.
*Sigh* I miss Tyler. Having him back for a while would be a big help. And twist the clock back to Grade Eleven - or forward to March - while you're at it!
Smudges, Caitlin.

Wednesday, Sept 24/03
So go figure. I have Strep Throat again. Right on schedule. *SIGH* Shoulda taken more Vitamin C...I knew working in the Food Service Industry was risky!At least I caught it quick. Woke up yesterday with rebellious tonsils and decided to give them 24 hours to decide what they were doing. Worse this morning, so I went to Dr Burilowski, and she put me on penicillin straight off, which hopefully means it was caught soon enough that it won't cause much trouble. I don't work again til Saturday, so fingers crossed...Hoping for a speedy recovery, Kits!
I appear to have stumbled back into this X-files obsession. Katy and I have been watching what few videos they have available here, and we've gotten up to Season Four, which is when I started watching. In my (biased) opinion, Seasons 4&5 were the best in the show - right in the middle when it was secure in its stride and still had interested actors, and interesting plots. They were able to take risks and develop the Mythology, but they hadn't degraded to bringing in bad Duchovny substitutes and rnning ridiculous plots. After Season Six it really wasn't worth watching, and after Season Seven I didn't, except the last episode. I mean, really, half the point of thhe show was the romantic tension between Scully and Mulder - stick Dogett in there and you lose the spark entirely. There were a few good ideas left hanging around, but really, they shoul dhave just called it quits when Duchovny did.
Anyway, I've been looking up episode synopses and transcripts from Season 4&5, cause we're almost out of episodes on video and the movie doesn't come in until after Season 5. And there's so much I'd forgotten! Wow. It was so weird to have it all come flooding back with just these vague synopses and keywords. So odd.
Really wish the series on DVD didn't cost $75 per season!
Anyway...I ramble. G'night, Kitty.
Sick smudges.

Thursday, Sept 25/03
"A clear conscience is usually a sign of a bad memory."
So. X-Files. Gawd, how did I ever let myself get involved in this mess again? This obsession. IT'S OVER! And I didn't even bother to WATCH the last two seasons. Really, out of a nine-season show, I only ever watched four seasons; that's less than half.
But Gawd. I loved those characters. Love those characters. They're fucking imaginary figures, but I cared so much about them. I was eleven and they promised me everything. And somehow, they still do. Today I downloaded the last episode of the show, "The Truth", the end of the Ninth season. I didn't even know there was a ninth season 0 I had thought the series ended with that kiss at the end of the eighth. I called it quits there. And really, I still don't have any se for the episodes that don't have Mulder. That show, for me at least, WAS Scully and Mulder. That relationship. I wasn't in love with David Duchovny (if anything, I was more attracted to Nicholas Lea, the guy who plays Alex Krycek); I was in love with Scully&Mulder. I was in love with love. With romance - with need and passion unrealized.
And I still am. I miss Tyler - desperately - but what I miss sometimes more is Tyler Before. Before we started going out. Before we said "I love you" like we took it forgranted. Before everything was a sure thing. No matter what the situation, nothing attracts me like desperation and need...desires half-admitted and promises almost fulfilled. I[t] took me a while to understand that romance and love aren't the same thing. Love is placid; love is prosaic. I love Tyler. I love talking ot him, I love bein gwith him, I love touching him. It's comfortable. It's nice. It's frustrating at the moment with him in bloody Nanaimo, but it's something you can count on, you know? It's secure.
But comfort isn't romance. And I hate to admit it, but it's a bit boring. Where's the danger, the uncertainty, the THRILL? People stay married for eighty years - but where's the tension? Where's the squeezing in your chest and the tingle in your palms when he hugs you spontaneously in the A&W parking lot and you think, Wow, could he really like me?
Don't take this wrong. I'm not about to break up with Tyler and go off on a quest for adventure. But I can't help wondering if this is it. I'm eighteen. What if I marry Tyler and live happily ever after? Will I never feel that emotional turmoil again in a non-vicarious medium? Or is there a way to take this for-granted affection, spice it up and make me thrill at it again? There must be. And then again, maybe I just need to see him...
*L, and maybe I'm just sick and overwrought. That's always a possibility too! :p
G'night, Kitty. Love you...

Wednesday, September 03/03
Hi. 
I hate delivering resumes. It's incredibly depressing. NOBODY's hiring. I need a job - I have NO MONEY! I wish I were going to school. Highschool, university - whatever, just get me out of this limbo! I've got an interview at Denny's tomorrow, and I really hope it pans out. It's not my first choice of places to work, but at the moment I'll take anything. Christ, and it's only been two days. But every place I apply they say they've just hired, or they aren't hiring until Christmas. Grrr. I am not cut out for unemployment. It's driving me nuts! I need to be doing something - I can't handle this!
Not that I'm not doing things. I've got piano lessons, music history lessons, voice lessons...I'm taking a third-year American Literature course through UNBC...I'm considering joining Sweet Adelines, Northwest Singers, Yoga, and/or the Musical...but its not an OCCUPATION.I need something steady. Everyone's employed. Everyone's at school or working. Katy complains about working for her dad, but she's got guaranteed full-time work at good wages until she's ready to leave. She's been working all summer. I've got no money in the bank and one prospect of working at a cheap restaurant part-time for minimum wage and I'm jumping at the chance. We are going to Europe in SEVEN MONTHS!! Fuck.
I hate stressing. Stop it, Cailtin. You are not improving matters in the slightest by rehashing all the bullshit in this journal!

I miss Tyler. My my, what a surprise. At least I managed to go almost a page before saying it. REally though, he helps a lot in terms of emotional stability. His presence is very anchoring. It's really hard having him so far away.
So far away...Doesn't anybody stay in one place anymore?
It would be so fine to see your face at my door
And it doesn't help to know that you're so far away...
Long ago I reached for you, and there you stood
Holding you again could only do me good
How I wish I could, but you're so far away
One more song about moving along the highway
Can't say much of anything that's new
If I could only work this life out my way
I'd rather spend it being close to you
But you're so far away
Doesn't anybody stay in one place anymore?
It would be so fine to see your face at my door..
And it doesn't help to know that you're just time away
So far away...you're so far away.
Carole King. Haven't thought about that song in a while. Fitting though, isn't it?
Wish me extra super especial luck with my interview tomorrow! 
Love you, Caitlin.

Thursday, Sept 04/03
So, I got the job at Denny's! Lol, I think it helped that pretty much EVERYONE who works there - including the cook - knows me. It was really funny.
The interview was so nerve-wracking! Well, no, not the interview itself, per se - that was fine. It was the anticipation that killed. I had to do Sun Salutations for half an hour beforehand to calm myself.
But I have a job! Granted, it'sa minimum-wage graveyard-shift job, but right now I'd take anything. I need money, and I need a schedule.
Orientation tomorrow at 2:30. Also have a bunch of platonic things to do like cleaning my bathroom and finding that stupid scholarship claim information. I don't know what my hours are going to be like yet, so I'm not going to apply anywhere else until I find out. But yay! I have a job! 
Employed smudges, Kitty. :)

Monday, September 8/03
First day of 'training' at Denny's was today. This largely means being slave labour and memorizing lame acronyms (the CAN Prevention Model: Be Consistent and Communicate; Be Attentive!; Meet the Needs.) And did you know that there are eight steps to washing your hands? Yes, eight.

Somehow Tyler has ceased to exist. That's not what I mean, but...well, it's like, there's no need or reason to miss him, because he doesn't exist in real life anyhow. He exists solely as a voice on the other end of the telephone line. And then sometimes I need him so badly.
Katy is leaving for Telegraph Creek tomorrow - unless she isn't. She was initially supposed to leave last Saturday (yes, a week and a half ago), and her Dad's been putting it off further and further since. They're going up there to do electrical stuff.
I'm desperately jealous of both her and Tyler. I want to be doing something steady. I want to know where I stand. I want steady money coming in, or else I want to be in a place where I'm not worried about money. I don't want this uncertainty, this foundering...
I know it'll all work out somehow, but it's so FRUSTRATING - they're both so productive and satisfied with what they're doing, and it feels like me and my juggling balls are still caught here in Limbo...
GRR. Dis-satisfied smudges.

Saturday, Sept 13/03
Ugh. Meant to get off the phone with Tyler an hour ago, but you know how that can be...now it's twenty to one, and I'm exhausted. Which makes sense, I suppose, seeing as I was up at 7 this morning, worked from eight til three, and only got seven hours of sleep last night. :p
It's been a crazy week. I've worked 3-8 hours every day since Monday - started being Official yesterday. Today was the busiest it's been, but yesterday was the most fun - I got to be a server. That's WAY more interesting, plus you get tips! I made $16 in tips last night in four hours, which isn't bad at all. Today I just did hostessing, which really isn't nearly as much fun. You don't get to interact as much with people, you don't get as much money, and there's a lot less work to keep you occupied. There's nothing worse than trying to look busy even when there's nothing left to do, trust me. You welcome the chance to fill sugars and bus tables! I swear, folding napkin and cutlery packages was the highlight of my day!

I really miss Tyler right now, these last couple days. I need him. Here. Physical presence. Christ, it's only the middle of September! He's only been gone two fucking weeks. The time's gone by quick within that period (I swear it was Monday last time I turned around), but it feels like tow MONTHS. And it's officially our seven-month anniversary today. Isn't that sad? And even so, I STILL keep track. Silly Caitlin. Well, after all, if I can't be foolish and girly in a private journal, than wehre can I do it?

Need sleep. Don't have to work tomorrow, hurray, but I want to give my room a good clean, etc.
September 11 came and went without a murmur. Funny how things change, isn't it?
G'night, Kitty. :)

Wednesday, Sept 17, 2003
Serving, as I may have said already, is WAY better than hostessing. There's a lot more to do to keep you busy, plus you make a lot more money. I've only served three times, and they were 4-hour shifts, but my tips during that time averaged out to about $6/hour - that's significant! $14 per hour looks a LOT prettier than eight!Katy got back today (she's been in Telegraph working for a week), which has returned my life to some semblance of normalcy. We went to the Pool(me)/Gym(Kt) tonight, which we haven't done in months. It was great - made me feel almost human!
...It's amazing how much I miss Tyler when I go to bed...it's so much more comfortable, somehow, with two... Tomorrow's my first eight hour shift (I did seven hours on Saturday) and I think I'm serving. I REALLY hope Ed and Becky are there, regardless. I can't stand R*y!

Have a good night in your world, Kitty, and I'll try to have a good one in mine. :) Goodnight!

Monday, August 4/03
I'm getting tired of writing death entries. One was about twenty too many for an eighteen-year-old. Two is devastating.
Jachin Estes, the cowboy with dreadlocks, is dead. He drowned yesterday, in Vancouver. He was a classmate of mine, but he dropped out of school this spring to help support his family when his father died. And yesterday he drowned. Isn't that sick. And the Lord said, 'I take from you your children and you say How blessed are we - you really need me; that's why I love Mankind.'
I didn't know him all that well - a bit better than I knew Hannah. I have more specific memories of him, anyway. I remember him in Crazy For You, the cowboy with dreadlocks wearing a silk shirt. I remember him from CAPP class, fiddling with his hair instead of taking notes. I remember him singing a song about jerking off at a coffee house last year.
Sounds like a winner, hunh? Well, I remember him playing guitar with Adam Kerby at Hannah's funeral, and being unable to sing cause he was so upset. I remember him holding a stron gtenor line throuhg all his goofing off in choir. I remember him spontaneously adding drums to the recording I did for Britt of her Music Theatre piece for the Rupert Dance Festival.
I remember Jachin Estes. I remember Hannah Kantola. I don't remember the two Rupert kids who died in a car crash last weekend or the seventeen-year-old girl whose father stabbed her to death in Kitimat two weeks ago, but I grieve for those that do remember them, and for the families and friends of everyone too young to have left life.
And selfish as it may be, I pray to whatever deity is runnin g this show that it doesn't happen to mine. Life isn't fair. It's just fairer than death, that's all.
Goodnight, Kitty.

Wednesday, Aug 6th
In the midst of all that, I forgot to tell you anything else, and now, as usual, I'm tired. 
I'm not at Skyline. Could you tell? Probably not. Well, I'm supposed to be at Skyline. We're supposed to be at Skyline. Fifty-five people are supposed to be at Skyline. None of us are.
Got as far as the orientation meeting on Sunday without realizing this. And guess what? Alberta's on fire. BC's on fire. The road to the road to the trailhead was closed Monday. There's fire quite literally in the valley next to our proposed basecamp. And they aren't kidding - you couldn't see any mountains from Banff today cause the smoke was so bad...Banff is surrounded by mountains!
Anyway. So instead, we spent a day in Drumheller (very cool museum, although they managed to totally avoid the process of human evolution, and an extremely surreal landscape), and now we're at Nana and Papa's house. Staying here til Saturday, then flying to Hamilton to commence the Ontario/Cammac section of this vacation/fiasco.
Very tired. More tomorrow, etc.
G'night Kitty.

Monday, Aug 18th
So, here's the situation. It was Wednesday, August 6th the last time I wrote in this journal. Now, it's the eighteenth. Why, you ask, has she been so very remiss in her journalistic (for lack of a better word) duties, particularly when she is on holidays and has therefore no stressful education-related concerns to lure her away?
Well, I shall tell you - as briefly as I am able given the typically-narrative style of my writing as well as its current unaccustomed verbosity for which I apologise profusely - I have been reading Robertson Davies, you see. At any rate, the point of the sentence (which, in my verbal meanderings, I never actually arrived at) was that I am - as usual - tired, and therefore attempting, despite all appearances to the contrary, to be brief. :)

My bag missed its flight. Brief enough for you? Those damnable fold-up scissors again. They turn up absolutely everywhere, and I never notice them until it's too late. They were in my overnight kit, which was in my carryon bag, because I never leave toiletries in my checked luggage in case it gets lost in transit (!!). This was particularly ironic considering that earlier that morning I had already removed from that bag not only my Swiss Army knife, but also my pencil sharpener (!!) in case they had a problem with it. Didn't notice the scissors.
Not, of course, that a pair of one-and-a-half inch nail scissors could possibly do anybody any particular harm anyway. (Any any any). I mean, you could do just as much damage with a sharpened PENCIL as you could with one of those things, for crying out loud! Oh great, now they'll read this and decide to ban pencils! But anyway...I suppose you have to draw the line somewhere, right? And they chose to draw it before my scissors. My choice (this was in the Kelowna airport, boarding - or rather not boarding - our WestJet flight to Hamilton) was to dispose of the scissors or check my carryon bag. Yes, yes, I know. In retrospect, those scissors weren't really so terribly important. Hindsight's 15/20. (Or else it's 20/15 - I can never remember which is the number that changes. Anyway.)
So I took out my book and my discman, and checked the backpack...and have been without my toiletries, my camera, or my journal (among other things) for a week.
Moral of the story? ...Next time, lose the scissors.
Gnight, luv. Caitlin.

Friday, August 29/03
I'm screwed up. Fix me. 
What is this? I don't cry. I DON'T CRY. I cried last night for like half an hour over something petty my dad said. Tonight I'm on the verge of tears again. I hate this.
I guess I've sort of got an excuse, but it isn't the sort of excuse I want to have, and it isn't the sort of excuse I want to use. Tyler's gone. I put him on the plane this morning at 7:30. Is that why I'm so upset? I've been ignoring it all day. It's not the sort of thing that I want to upset me. I hate being a Girl, moping cause my boyfriend left and making everyone else's lives miserable because I'm upset. It feels so childish. THIS feels so childish. Tyler's gone. I'm not going to see him again for four months. It feel slike the end of the world, and I hate that. I hate fucking emotional attachment. It just makes it worse that I have to pretend to be cool about it, have to pretend everything's fine. I don't want people to think less of me - they wouldn't, of course, but I have a hard time knowing that.
*RANT TO BE CONTINUED LATER*

Sunday, August 31/03
note to self: it is a STUPID idea to go anywhere near a computer any time after midnight if you have any intention of getting sleep that night. Now it's twenty after one. I MEANT to go to bed early. Better than last night, though - I was up until 4:30 (yes, that is a four) reading the fifth Harry Potter book. At least I finished it though, so that particular brand of foolishness cannot be repeated. But I feel the need to write in this journal, so it might be two before I go to sleep...oh well.
I'm a lot better than I was last time you heard from [me]. Two days and a lot of chickflicks are good therapy for a heart that has been "like gold to airy thinness beat." =p *is a nerd* I interrupted the previous segment of this entry cause Katy came to interrupt me - or rather, to rescue me from that messy business of wallowing in self-pity. We watched Ever After, drove around Lakelse Lake (almost literally) and went to Mike's going-away party (he's moving to Vancouver to attend a dance academy), which was actually a lot more fun than I expected it to be. I hadn't seen people in a long time and it was fun to have a chance to talk to everyone. I even missed TRAVIS! Now that's saying something! I got bored and antisocial (and tired - did I mention Tyler and I only got about 2 hours of sleep on Thursday night?), but managed to have fun anyway: Barry entertained me, and I had a bit of a conversation with Britt's guy, Stefan, who's also from Rupert. He's a really nice guy.
So, at any rate I've been keeping busy. It's still bothering me, though - Tyler's gone. I'm not sure I've quite registered FOUR MONTHS yet. Once Katy's not here to help distract me it'll probably sink in. Even as it is, though, I've been in a lot of inexplicably bad moods over the last couple days, and I suspect that's the result of combined upset and stress about the prospect of getting a job. I do hope not to get quite so distraught again as I was on Friday - I'd say I was sorry, but then, I suppose that listening to melodramatic outpourings is your job, isn't it, Kitty? And anyway, it can't be any worse than a lot of the other drivel I've written in here. Lol, Tyler says this journal [is] very silly and teeny-bopper-ish, and I suppose he's right. It's my vent for releasing thoughts and emotions I consider too petty/juvenile/ridiculous to actually voice aloud. At heart, there is, unfortunately, a part of me that really truly is a teenager. If I'm not allowed to be ridiculous in here, then where can I?
At any rate, that outburst on Friday was nevertheless uncommon for me. I was just feeling so trapped and upset...it was likely a combination of tiredness, stubbornness, and the fact that we really did not have a very satisfactory goodbye - he was in such a hurry by the time we got to the airport that there wasn't any time...my MOTHER said goodbye to him more thorouhgly than I did! 
But it's water under the bridge.
Going to sleep...and it's only quarter to 2!
Goodnight, 'hon. Lovelorn smudges. :)

Tuesday, July 1st - Canada Day!

So, there's these two muffins in a tray and they get put in the oven. They're sitting there, and after a while, one says to the other, "My it's getting hot in here" and the other one says, "Ahh, a talking muffin!"
Lol, a drunk person told me that joke last night. He thought he was very funny. Actually, he was - but we were laughing more at him than the joke!

I've been very remiss with this journal - mostly cause Tyler's been here, but that's still no excuse.
I've officially graduated now. Ceremony was on Friday. I am never going to be a highschool student again - isn't that scary?! I think so. It's so weird to think about. Being out. Being done. Gawd. I've been doing this forever.
The Dry Grad party was fun - way better than Prom. It was very well organized, well-supplied, and well-run. It was set up like a carnival, with booths and games and prizes. Free food nd free stuff - what more can you ask for, right?! Anything that can keep me entertained until 5am is a pretty skookum outfit, though, is all I've got to say.
Ooh, and I got my Class 5 license! That means I'm a fully qulaified driver and I don't have to wear a stupid "N" on my tail anymore. I took my test for it last Thursday. Apparently I need to stop further behind the stop lines - but my observation skills are great! And he didn't even test any of the things I was worried about - parallel parking, tire position when parking on hills, and the functional capabilities of my parking break (which are less than stellar.) It was great.
My grandparents - Dad's parents, that is, not Nana and Papa - have been up for about a week; they're leaving tomorrow. I love them, but they're tough to be around. I never know what to do around them; I'm always on edge.
Tyler's looking for a job in Terrace over the summer. He needs money for university next year, and there's no work in Rupert. Not that the odds are much better here, but there are some opportunities. If he moves here, he'll be living with Katy, in the other half of her parents' basement suite. THAT should be an interesting experience!
G'night Kitty. :)

Monday, July 7th/03
I've just left my boyfriend at my best friend's house for the night - for  the summer, actually. It's a most peculiar feeling. Tyler managed to get a job here (finaly) at the College, as a library assistant. He starts tomorrow - and he also, officially, starts living at Katy's house.He's renting the other half of her basement suite - I'm not sure if I told you. They're giving him a really great deal; he's only paying a hundred dollars a month, plus food, which amounts to barely anything in relative terms. It's a great thing for him...that is, if they can make it work.
Katy and Tyler have been having issues - I'm fairly positive I told you that. They're mostly sorted out for the moment, but there's always this degree of tension between them, so it will be very interesting to see if they can survive living together for two months without murderin geach other. I'm afraid it's going to strain all of our relationships, but if they can survive it, I think it will be good for both of them...and maybe even myself as well.
It's weird from my perspective though, undoubtedly. I didn't think having him living there would bother me, and it doesn't exactly, per se. I mean, he spends a lot more time NOT here than he does at my house - but always before, when he's not been here he's been in Rupert. Now, it's different, somehow. It's odd to leave him down the street at Katy's house, to not have him here and know that he's only two blocks away. I'm not used to him being inTerrace and not being with me. It doesn't seem fair...I know that it IS fair, of course, plus I don't get nearly enough sleep at night or enough things accomplished during the day when he's here.
If nothing else, it'll be an interesting process, to say the least.
G'night, Kitty. :)

Thursday, July 10th/03
Oof. It's 1am, I just spent an hour walking around with Tyler, and I'm definitely ready to sleep. However, I feel I ought to write, if only briefly, if for no other reason than that I am EIGHTEEN. Isn't that terrifying?! I'm older than Rolf! Aren't I supposed to become mature or wise or something at some point? As usually, this does not feel dundamentally any different from being seventeen. Eighteen does at least create some milestones, though. Aside from the fact that I am now officially my own person in the eyes of the law, I can also vote in municipal and provincial (but not federal) elections, rent pornography, and buy alcohol in Alberta. Two of these prospects are considered particularly appealing to the teenage populace in general - guess which two!Katy, Tuna, Lowell, and I are leaving on our Jasper Adventure on Sunday - I fully expect the next two days to be insane!

Entrepid smudges. G'night, Kitty. :)

Wednesday, July 16th, 2003
We are now on our fourth day of our Jasper Adventure. It's been beautiful so far, but this morning we woke up to rain. I'm sure this is our fault somehow, but I can't decide whether it's because we decided to go on a hike today or because I forgot to bring my gortex. Katy says we also mustn't forget about the fact that we prematurely packed the sandwiches for the hike last night, and left our last piece of paper out in the open by the firepit. I think these trangressions should have been countered by the fact that I zipped up the vestibule of the tent in case it rained, but I guess it wasn't enough...

Sorry - it's now the (late) evening of Thursday July 17th, and we're having a Journal Writing session. This evening has been...eventful. In a talking-about-guys way. David and Chris, mostly...Katy's guys.
*sigh* Think I'm going to have to stop again. We're almost done our Adventure! Tomorrow is our last real day; we're going to the Hotsprings, and then Saturday we're leaving. I think we're taking two day sto come home so we can look at second-hand bookstores in PG.
Try to write again before returnign home. Goodnight! :)

Wednesday, July 23/03
I am TERRIBLE with this journal lately! I just never get around to updating anymore!I didn't write again while we were camping. Surprise. :p It was fun, though. It's a neat feeling to be genuinely fending for yourself. We took two days coming back - stayed with KT's Aunt and Uncle in PG and looked around at 2nd-hand-book stores in the area. Found some neat books!
Anyway. We've been back since Sunday night, and I've been busy enjoying my two weeks of Summer At Home before we're off again (next Friday) to Skyline and Cammac (with Mum and Dad, respectively.) Somehow this summer seems way shorter than last summer (already!) although really, I'm spending almost exactly the same amount of time away. It's odd. I'm enjoying having Tyler in town, although balance issues with Katy have been borderline weird. It's extremely odd having them both living in the same space. I'm going to miss Tyler A LOT when he leaves in the fall - remind me to go into my speculations on THAT front another time...

And I have GOT to get over this Obsession! ( I know this seems like a jump, but it makes sense in my head.) Up until Grade 6, it made sense. In grades 7 & 8, when I had no friends anyhow, I can understand clinging to the vestiges. But why is my subconscious still Obsessed with Brad?! It's ridiculous! Eventually, I'm gonna have to write to him or SOMETHING...find a way of putting this ghost to rest. In the past two weeks, I've had two vivid, powerful, emotional, and very romantic dreams about him. WHY? It's like this book that I never finished reading - I've mostly forgotten the plot by now, and it's completely irrelevant to the rest of my life, and it SHOULDN'T MATTER, but I still can't help wondering what happened, even though even if I now had that information, it would no longer make sense to me. Oh, nevermidn. It's just so SILLY, that's all. I had that crush in Grade 6, and yet I've just graduated highschool and I still can't help dwelling on it. Am I pathetic or what?!
Gnight, Kitty. :)

Sunday, July 27th
Bleached my hair and dyed it blue today. Yes, I'm serious. I've been wanting to do it for years and never had the guts. Katy's is purple. We're so rebellious. :p Tyler says I actually AM A rebellious teenager and just nobody ever realizes it cause I'm rebelling from the wrong things - that is, my parents always expected me to be radical, and therefore by being inhibited and "perfect" I am symbolically thwarting their plans.

It'll be especially interesting having [blue] hair since we're leaving in less than a week to go to Skyline and CAMMAC. I think the most interesting thing will be to see how adults whom I don't know treat me - whether their attitude changes as a result of the colour of my hair. Lol, maybe I should keep a travelogue of my encounters. I'll call it "Blue Like Me." Yes, I know that was terrible. Sorry.

Better go. Blue smudges, Kitty. :)

Monday, June 9th, 2003
Despite the intended privateness of this journal, i somehow perpetually feel tht I am writing for an audience, and as such there are certain things I have a very hard time talking about ever here, though I feel the need to vocalize them. I'm just too damned inhibited!
Last weekend was Prom. (No, we didn't have sex, that's not what I mean. Why is Prom night always associated with sex anyways? It's so stupid...) Tyler came up of course, as did Martina. It was kind of lame - the parading around in dresses & getting hair done & taking pictures beforehand was way more fun than the actual dinner and dance. That was...well, a lot like a school dance. Loud, mostly. Tyler and I discovered that we really can't dance together, not properly. When I was wearing high heels it sort of works, but otherwise it was totally useless.
I'm very weird about kissing in public. I hate it. It embarasses me - I'm SO inhibited! Gah. But it's not even that, it's like...I dunno, like I don't want to make other people uncomfortable. Lol, despite the fact that everyone else does it! Tyler kept trying to kiss me, and I kept shying away.
After we left the Prom it was more fun. We went to Katys', and some people drank while others of us laughed at them. There was an actual after-party at Josh Foot's house which got broken up by the cops at 3:30, but I had absolutely no desire to go to that.
I'm so weird about alcohol. I really can't figure me out. I honestly wish that it would just cease to exist. It's not that I desire alcohol, I don't - I don't even LIKE it - it's just that it makes me massively resentful whenever other people are drinking, because I can't. My only experiences with alcohol have been either totally ineffective in terms of changing my character, or else completely miserable. I've never been successfully drunk - or buzzed, or tipsy, or whatever. I've been sober, and I've been sick. That's it.
And I hate it. If anyone needs to loosen up, it's me. So why can't I? I hate watching everybody else have a good time, it's SO unfair.
But anyways. Meaningless bitching. Tyler doesn't drink either - like, he DOESN'T...like refuses - he says he's got a really addictive personality and it's way too tempting. Like drugs. We stayed and laughed at drunk people - in other words everybody else except Will, and David and Amy when they appeared for 5 minutes. Then we went home...and made out.
Making out is really weird, if you actually think about the process. I've said this before, but it's still true. And despite the ludicrousness of the equation Prom = Sex (actually, I think the whole prom thing in general is fairly ridiculous), there is this bizarre impetus to, you know, go further. So we did. I mean, we do usually anyways. Tyler and I approach making out like the Adult Beginner Alfred's Basic book. We introduce new concepts so gradually and subtly you don't notice you're changing things until suddenly you're miles away from Square One. But Saturday we wound up places where Tyler didn't know what he was doing either, which was really weird. I'm so used to him running the show - he's the one with the driver's license, so to speak. I've only got my L. Most peculiar.
Lol, and we weren't the only ones. Will and Tyra made out at Katy's, as did Katy and Chris. In terms of them, it's about time. They've been going out for over a month and have kissed once! But alcohol remedied that. :p Lol I know that sounds terrible - they're both too shy to initiate anything normally; they almost need an artificial situation to break the barrier.
I'd better go to sleep: it's 11:37 and a Monday. We're staying at Katy's grandma's again housesiting. Feels like old times. Last time we were here was October. I told Tyler I liked him.

Sometimes this journal feels like a gossip column.
G'night! :)

Thursday, June 12th, 2003
I suppose I should write, considering that tonight - or rather, tomorrow - is somewhat of a milestone in my life. Tomorrow - yes, Friday the 13th - is the official last day of school for my grade twelve year. Four exams and a couple of ceremonies follow, but after tomorrow I will never again have a scheduled grade school class.
That's terrifying! On the one hand, I'm INCREDIBLY glad to have it finally over with - I've been officially Tired of School for months now - but at the same time, I find it terribly upsetting. The social aspect of it more than anything really. There are so many people that I hardly even notice at school - and yet I'll miss them terribly when they're no longer there...there are so many people that I know it's inevitable I'll lose contact with, and I find that so sad. I'll miss them. I can't help wondering what ten years will do to people...
It's people like Ken Adair who scare me the most. I'm so afraid of returning for a ten-year reunion to find that he killed himself a year from now...it's way too likely and that's way too terrifying.
It's also, coincidentally, mine and Tyler's four-month anniversary. Isn't that sad? A "four-month anniversary"? Highschool relationships are so ridiculous. I mean, celebrating that you've been together a MONTH! That's no time at all. I can understand a year - even four months - but every month? Seems ridiculous, but people seriously make a big deal of it. Tyler and I don't...actually, I don't think we've ever even been in the same town on one of those occasions...lol which I suppose is symbolic, considering we also weren't in the same town the night he asked me out!

Katy and I had so much fun this evening! It was hilarious. We decided at around 8pm to go for a walk - there was a light drizzle (about time; it's been unelievably gorgious for absoluately WEEKS), but not much to worry about...until about halfway throuh our walk. At which point it turned into an absoluate torrential downpour. You could barely SEE for the rain. Lol, it was great! We rolled up our pantlegs and took of our shoes and socks (or sandals, in my case) and waded through every puddle we could find. Got absolutely SOPPING wet. Froze our asses off too, but that's a secondary concern. Hope we don't catch pneumonia. It was SO much fun, though. I haven't done anything so silly in a long time and I'd forgotten...
Anyway...want to be alive for my LAST DAY OF SCHOOL tomorrow, so I'd better go to sleep. Many happy returns of the day and all that, Kitty. (Lol, shut up, I don't know!)

PS Her grandmother has this amazingly annoying Cockatoo (or something) named Stupid. It says "Hello birdie" whenever you enter the room, and whistles - yes WHISTLES - the Andy Griffith theme song.
Which, by the way, I swear I know from Fred Penner and not Andy Griffith. I've never even SEEN Andy Griffith.
G'night.


Tuesday, June 17th, 2003

The letter to Tyler. Guess what exploded:
Writing in my journal would probably make more sense, since you're not going to get this for days anyhow, but I desperately want to talk with you, and this is the net best thing.
Funny - there are few things that make me as happy as a really good discussion with you - and there are few things that upset me as much as a really awful one.
The last time I cried, I was twelve. I've now cried three times in the past month. I fucking hate emotional turmoil.
I've been playing the part of the rope in games of tug-of-war since grade two, when my two best friends decided they hated each other, and it hasn't gotten any easier. I don't think you ever quite get used to the sensation of being ripped apart.
I know that sounds adolescent and melodramatic, but that's honestly how it feels sometimes. I refuse to assign blame - mostly because the main person I'd assign blame to is myself. Sometimes it feels like all I ever do is destroy other people's friendships - I'm always caught in the fucking middle. Maybe it's selfish of me to want everythign at once, but I love you both way too much to ever let either of you go. You're both such intricate parts of my soul...
I don't mind mountains so long as you can see that there's another side...sometimes it feels like this will never be right.
I don't have a whole lot to say on paper. I need to talk to you. Fuck, I just need you, period. It's so hard, to not have you coming. I need you here so badly...
I love you.
PS I don't mean this to be the least bit accusatory..I'm sorry if it comes off that way. I'm glad you said what you felt, cause bottled-up emotions never benefitted anyone...I just with that the problem wasn't there to begin with.
Caitlin.

Sunday, June 22nd/03
I'm finished Highschool. Do you realize how terrifying that is?! I have one more provincial (French) on Tuesday, and then I'm really, officially done. "The end of an Era", as Katy would say. Tyler's moving into the other room down there in about a week, or whenever he finds a job. On the 11th(ish) of July, Katy, Lowell, Martina, and I are going camping in Jasper for a week, and then in August I've got Skyline and CAMMAC, so I'm gone for another three weeks.

Tyler and Katy. Are you confused? They appear to be at each others' throats and yet they're going to be living in the same space. Maybe I should explain, but I don't really know what to tell you...
There's tension. That's obvious. It's okay right now. A week ago it wasn't, but we've had some minor explosions since then, and I think things are fairly stable.
I think it's mostly my fault, or at least I'm the fulcrum (crux) of the problem. They, for lack of a better word, fight over me. I actually think it will be good for them to spend some concentrated time together without me there - it will sort things out. 

Should probably go to sleep. Have to study and clean my car tomorrow. Katy starts her new job at 9am...wish her luck!! The new Harry Potter book - the fifth one, the "Order of the Phoenix" came out yesterday. Everyone's very excited. I haven't read it yet, though I intend to. I'd like to read the end of the fourth one againfirst, though...
G'night... :)

Saturday, May 10th/03

I cried today - like physical tears and sobs, not just leaking - for the first time in six years. I quite literally haven't cried since I was 12years old - and the release felt great! Well, after the fact. I remember now why I hate crying so much. Two main reasons: first, it's extremely inelegant. I mean, I suppose everybody's inelegant when they cry, but I feel that I look particularly undignified. It contorts all my features and I can't help making choky sobbing sounds...I hate letting my guard down like that, being so vulnerable. Also, it always feels likea guilt trip if there's anyone around. That's silly, of course...if I can't cry even when I most want to, it's obviously not a skill I can access on command. But it still feels that way.
Particularly today. The situation was thus: we were in Rupert. (lol, and if you've been following the Kaitylin Show regularly this season, perhaps that's explanation enough.) Tons of people were with us - Eric, Lance, and Cayley as wel as me, Katy, Tyler, and Martina, plus al the dancers who were already up for the Rupert competition; in other words Tyra, Jessica, Lindsay (Tyra's siter), Mike, and Hans, among other people. Essentially, everyone but Chris.
This, understandably, was a problem for Kt. Tensions built, most (understandably) directed towards me and Tyler. See, part of the problem is that Tyler's incredibly clingy. Like, doesn't want to be a separate entity from me so long as we're in the same room, and wants never to be in a room without me. Katy has issues with his attachment to my hip. It's understandable. It's like...I duno, like he usurps her position or something.
The second problem, though, is purely me, and it isn't at all fair (I mean, I'm not fair._ See, I blame Katy for everything. I mean, jokingly we blame everything on Tyler, but in all seriousness I almost always pass plame and evil on to Katy. I've got this complex where not only must I always be right and know everything, I must also be a wonderful, kind person while I'm at it. And so Katy always has to be bad cop, and it's completely unjust.
Katy thought I was crying because SHE was a horrible person...I was crying because I am. 
I've got to start writing earlier...I have this dilemma where I don't wnat to sketch over events, but simultaneously I want to finish and sleep.
I try, I try. G'night, Kitty. :)

Friday, May 23rd/03
I'm supposed to call Tyler at 2 o'clock (yes, AM; yes, it's stupid), which is in fifteen minutes, so I suppose I might as well update.But it takes so long to give adequate coverage of everything...
I think the Honeymoon's over. It ended two days ago - Wednesday. There weren't any blow-ups or anything; we didn't even fight particularly, it wasn't like that. Things changed. There are definitely Problems that need sorting out. The ironic part is, you've already heard about these problems - I've acknowledged them on a personal level for months. It boils down to lack of emotion - that's the problem. I can't express emotion. I believe "Love is not a reply" is the phrase he used - that is to say, I never initiate emotional exchanges. It's true. The hardest part of it for him, I think - the most obvious part - is the phrase "I love you". I'm incapable of saying that unless he says it first. Will not do it.  And the reason is ridiculous...
I'm terrified. That's the crisis point, plain and simple. I'm absolutely, ludicrously paranoid about losing affection. Whenever I haven't seen or talked to Tyler in a couple of days, I'm irrationally terrified that he's forgotten me, or stopped caring. 80% of me knows that's ridiculous. 20% of me is still afraid to admit it's real. I guess I've gone so long without romantic reciprocity that it's tough to accept...somewhere along the lines, I began assuming that no one was ever going to care about me like that. I'm seventeen and I know that's immensely illogical, but then, teenagers aren't known for their logic, generally. I could never see why anyone WOULD like me - there are so many beautiful, interesting girls out there; why would anyone like me? I don't know how to respond to people, so I'm always awkward and shy and boring when I meet people, and I'm not particularly attractive, physically - I don't fit together properly. I know these things. I accept them. Problem IS, though, when you've lived resigned to that mindset for five years, it's awful hard to change.

Saturday, May 24th/03
I guess I'm oblivious. Well, I mean, apparently.
It's 3AM and I just got off the phone with Tyler, when I called, as per instructions, at 1. Had an interesting discussion, the most informative part of which occurred after I was already trying to gt off the phone. We started talking about hitting on people, and then about the first couple weeks  we knew each other.
Apparently he was flirting with me constantly - news to me! He says he was attracted to me immediately (which I, horribly, find really difficult to comprehend) and was essentially focussing all of his attention on me - attention that he thought I was aware of and reciprocating. Can you flirt subconsciously? Can you flirt with your eyes without knowing you're doing it? Thing is, I automatically assume guys aren't hitting on me...you've heard this bit before. I would never assumed that somebody was flirting with ME. Also ironic: that first night at Caroline's house. He says that of the people there, I was the only one he'd have been comfortable with touching him. Thing is, Tyra, Katy, and Martina had already jumped him, adn he looked so uncomfortable and I felt so sorry for him that I left him almost completely alone.
Wierd/stupid how happy that makes me.
Talking to Tyler has put me in a much better mood than I was in 3 hours ago - tonight, I was a NINTH wheel! Katy, Chris, David, Amy, Amanda, Matt, Katrina, Danny, and I were at David's watching Donnie Darko. I shared Chris, but it really wasn't the same.
Lol. Tyler like me! :p
'Night, Kitty. :)

Friday, May 30th/03
Had a Rocky Horror party tonight at KT's.
