Tuna and I were Janet at various stages, Lance was Brad (he was adorable - Katy sewed him a plaid tie and cummerbund, and we got some tortoiseshell glasses for him from Mum's 3rd-World eyecare box - I think his was the most perfect costume), Kurt as RiffRaff (including tails and hump! but no hair...), Jessica as Columbia, Cayley as Magenta, Eric as Frank, Hans as Rocky (yes, golden underwear only!!), and Ender (very impressively) as Eddie. Plus miscellaneous people (Chris learned the joys of possessing breasts, for example.) Tyler couldn't come...
Argh, I can't concentrate - I do want to rant about this, but I'd rather do a decent job. Tomorrow?
'Night. :)

April 24th/03

Hello again. I just wrote a letter to Tyler, and I think I'm basically going to transcribe it for you here, cause most of it could easily double as a journal entry...
We got to Whistler this evening, after a long but generaly uneventful busride. Played at a Secondary School in Quesnel (stupid idea!) this morning and got "sexually harassed" (other people's words) by some of the male students on the way out. One of the guys told Cayley (who's a flautist, if you didn't know) that she could "play his flute anytime." Afterwards, she was talking to me about it and was like, "What the fuck? Does he even know how you PLAY a flute?! I mean, what, does he want me to blow on the side of it?!"
I don't much care for Whistler...actually, in all honesty it kind of disgusts me. It tries way way too hard to be cute and perfect - and in my opinion, it overdoes it by a long shot. It's not a town! It's...Disneyland. And everything is astonishingly expensive. I mean, I was expectin ghtat, but...wow. We found a pair of pants in a store for $150 that I bought at Warehouse One a month ago for $30! That's a significant difference...
And Dylan has the exact same deodorant as Tyler, and it's really bothering me...he smells like him (sorry, bad pronoun reference...) Seriously, though, it's a problem. It makes me miss him every time Dylan's in the room And David and Amy cuddling doesn't help! *Sigh* I'm pathetic. 
And so's Katy! She's been going through Chris-withdrawal. She tried to call him tonight, but they won't let us call outside the hotel from our rooms (even though she has a calling card), and there was a mile-long lineup for the payphone in the lobby.
'Tennyrate, I'm going to sleep. Choir performs tomorrow morning, then Concert Band in the afternoon and Jazz Band at night. Wish us luck!
Smudges. :)

Friday, April 25th/03
Choir sucked...well, no, that's unfair. "Gate Gate" was pretty good. But "Rattle on the Stovepipe" was too slow and "All Ye Who Music Love" was way too fast. But Jazz Band was good! "Basie" could have been better, but at least it's over. "Missing You" was good, even though I don't think much of the song itself. David's solo was awesome! And "Feelin' Alright" was probably the best we've ever played it. I hated the piano in the venue though. It sounded really tinny, and was hyper-touch-sensitive, which is worse than not being touch-sensitive, in my opinion. You have no control over dynamic levels whatsoever. Very annoying.
Gawd, I miss Tyler. I'ts so pathetic - I saw him on Monday. Monday! That's only five days ago. Feels like a month. Doesn't make sense, but the longer we're together at a time, the more I miss him when he leaves. We were together from Thursday til Monday - it was wonderful.
I don't mean for this to turn into an overshare journal, but - wow. There's stuff I need to say, and Katy doesn't want to hear it, for obvious reasons. For starters, I never realized until this weekend that I genuinely cared about being told I'm beautiful. That I have a "great body" (in a good way! Lol nevermind...) But I do, apparently...care, I mean. It was such an astonishing ego-boost. I felt good about myself for days afterwards - isn't that sad? I wish we lived in a culture with less ridiculous perceptions of beauty...cause see, I still dont' buy it. I can't believe that I'm beautiful (whatever that means). But I can believe that Tyler believes it, and for the moment at least that's more than enough.
I love it...going out with him. I'm parched for affection, and if there's on thing Tyler's good at, it's feeding that need (ooh, sorry, mixed metaphor...alright, STARVED for affection then.) And I love physical discoveries. I love making out. I love the freedom to touch and be touched. I love exploration. I'm glad that he knows what's going on and how to direct things, cause otherwise I'd be totally lost. The first few times we made out, it was awkward, but now that I've ot some idea of what the fuck I'm supposed to be doing, it's so much fun. I don't know how to judge speed in relationships, and sometimes this feels fast, but if it is I don't care.
We had an interesting discussion about sex on Sunday night. He said he promised his mother (even though he now realizes it was an unfair promise to make without my consent) that we wouldn't sleep together (in the non-platonic sense, that is) until we were married. In all honesty, it was the "until" in that sentence that bothered me more than anything else. I have serious problems with that. Don't get me wrong; I'm not saying Tyler and I don't have a future together - I just don't feel in a position at this point in time to determine the outcome one way or the other. At any rate, that's beside the point. The point is, Tyler promised to practice abstinence. And he is, by the way, a vergin.
I guess my main issue with abstinence is hypocrisy. Practicing the letter of the law rather than the spirit, if you will. It bothers me to do everything but, as it were. It seems hypocritical somehow to still claim abstinence when you've done everything in your power to derive sexual pleasure without physically inserting Tab A into Slot B. But what do I know? Heck, I don't even believe in abstinence in the first place, so what does it matter? As I said to Tyler, we'll burn that bridge when we come to it.
More to write on the subject(s), but I'm falling asleep a the wheel here. :) G'night! :)

Thursday, May 1st
Fuck. I am without a doubt THE most selfish, unreasonable, and ridiculous person I know. It's driving [me] fucking NUTS! Chris got MSN, which is great because it means we finally get to berate him about whether or not he likes Kt. Yesterday, Tuna snagged him (I wasn't on) and started in that vein. So, fine. Today, I came online and he was on but so was Tuna and he won't talk to me about it cause he's already talking to her. It's FUCKING ANNOYING! Do you see how unfair this is?! I mean, do you see how unfair I'm being?! It's ridiculous. But I can't stand not being in control. I can't stand having her be asking the questions. BLAH.
Rant Rant Rant. Ignore me. It's probably just a side-effect of being sick and stressed out. (I have strep-throate agian, surprise surprise.)
Gnight.

Saturday, May 3rd/03
Ooh ooh! The BIG NEWS: Katy and Chris are going out! As of last night. I can't believe it happened so quickly... Following the above rant, I eventually got to actually talk to Chris, and we had quite a long, complicated conversation about walls, fears, etc. By the end of it, I was pretty sure they'd eventually go out. However, I must admit I was not expecting it to happen the next day! I had a sort of mental time-frame of minimum two weeks til showtime in my head. But this works too. And get this, it wasn't even a romantic movie like What Dreams May Come that we were watching - it was Requiem for a Dream, a fascinating and beautifully-filmed...but grim...movie about drug addicts. Chris is a sucker for creepy movies. :P
Anyways, it's late, I didn't get much sleep last night, I'm still recuperating, and I have tons to do tomorrow, but I had to get that out of my system. I do have a tone more to write, on that and related topics (cough Tyler cough), and I'll do my best to write tomorrow, but we all know how successful that tends to be...
'Night! :)

Friday, March 21st, 2003
warning for minor relationship overshares.
...And that, if you'll notice, was as near as no matter to two weeks ago. Am I predictable, or what?!Yeah, so nun swere cool. You got the drift. Waiting around in the Terrace airport for 45 minutes for a taxi wasn't cool, but whatever. Better than the initially proposed alternative, which was to fly to Fort St John for fuel and then back to Vancouver...they thought weather would be too bad to land in Terrace or Rupert, but thankfully we made it.
Just in time for war. It's official. The USA is bombing Iraq. Let's not get into it - I don't feel like being depressed and I don't feel like being pissed off and if you're curious there are undoubtedly news archives covering the event. War is Peace. Freedom is Slavery. Ignorance is Strenght. It's all over the news - it IS the news - and I can't help seeing it in comparison to the coverage of Septebmer 11th. That was a tragedy. This is necessary military action. One marine died yesterday. The USA is in mourning. This species is sick. 

But that's not what I meant to talk about, as I said. I meant to talk about Tyler.
Hmmm. Tyler. Too many things to say and I don't know where to begin. Okay, first off, I don't know how to kiss. I realized that this week - the first time we've kissed (practically the first time we've seen each other) since we started going out. I really just don't know how - I've never had the opportunity to learn! Katy says to just let him do everything, then, but I don't even know how to do that. Part of the problem is that our heads were on the wrong sides - I have this weird thing where I just don't understand how you can kiss with your head tilted left; I need it tilted right - but mainly I just don't know what to do. I don't know what I'm supposed to do with my tongue, for example, among other things.

Oh well. Strange problems. It's a peculiar predicament. The funniest thing about our relationship though, I think, is how different are our approaches to romance. Tyler is a romantic - he's very sappy. He loves pining when we're apart, and telling me he loves me, and finding sappy yet appropriate love songs. Whereas I am not. Sure, I miss him. I miss him constantly. But I don't pine about it. Am I a horrible person if I'm not yet utterly convinced that this counts as love? I don't get the love concept. I guess according to Tyler's definition I am in love with him. The world's a better place when he's in the room. I think about him too much and everything reminds me of him. I light up when he's there and all my attention is focussed on him. Is that love? Maybe (probably) I'm just too cynical. Whatever. But I am not a very good romantic - I'm far too pragmatic.

Nevertheless, I do miss him. I missed him a lot tonight - we were watching a movie, and I realized how long it's been since I last watched a movie without Tyler. I needed him there. I needed to cuddle with him. It was so frustrating.

Spring Break's practically over and it just started. We've had a busy time. Festival rehearsals. Went to Rupert. Finished Hans's album (finally!) Festival starts on Monday, and my first solo stuff is a week from then. Scary, but it's coming together.

Funny (jumping back a topic, sorry) how every step of the way I've pushed this relationship and now here we are and he's making all the moves and he's the one who fell. Go figure, hunh? 
I could write more, but it's 20 minutes after two in the morning (Saturday) and I do need to sleep so I can accomplish things. Tomorrow's a possibililty, but I make no promises. :)
Sleepy smudges. 'Night, Kitty. :)

Tuesday, March 4th/03

MARDI GRAS - Fat Tuesday. Almost too tired to write tonight, but here we are. I'll be brief.
Moved from Cozumel to Valladolid today, and we'll be staying here the rest of the week til we catch the plane home from Cancun on Saturday. Valladolid's a nice town - more like reality and less like a tourist trap for the staggeringly wealthy. However, it is, in fact, Mardi Gras today (last night before Lent, for the lay among you, *L*) so it's plenty crowded and pretty noisy, even here and even at 10 o'clock at night. I can hear the music from the Plaza across the street through the door...nice enough, but very loud, and extremely heavy with the bass.
This town's really funky - it was established by Conquistadores in the 16th century, so the architecture's amazing. Fabulous church across the square (Katy would love it), and this hotel we're staying at is precious near 500 years old. Very cool. 

What else? Saw neat caves today - cenotes, the Mayans called them - at Aktun-Chen, on the way driving out here. Really cool...the Mayans used them as shelter from hurricanes as well as a source of fresh water and clay for pottery, and lots of them used to be submerged, so there were fossils of shellfish in amongst the stalactites.
Got to an Internet Cafe! And got to talk to Tyler again. He's sick and his cat's lost - I think I'm having more fun than him, lol. But it's very sad about Nezgris - I hope he turns up; he's an adorable cat! He cuddled with me...Spiff and Sasha never do that voluntarily. 
And got to try a real coconut, finally, or at least the juice. Not something I'd want to drink everyday, but an interesting experience.
Sorry about the brevity of this entry, but I'm awful tired. 'Night! :)

Wednesday, March 5th/03 - Ash Wednesday
Again I'm going to try not to write for very long, since we're getting up early tomorrow morning to go to Chichen Itza! 
This morning was hot, but cool. (No pun intended, lol). We walked through the town - which is arranged so bizarrely; all the greenery is inside the walls, in courtyards in the middle of the blocks...it's a very foreign concept to me. The architecture was neat, though. Finally, we got to this Nunnery, which is one of the oldest buildings in Valladolid. It was realy cool! I would have spent more time there, despite the heat, but they closed it down for siesta after we'd been there maybe an hour. Neat building, though. The walls were amazingly thick, and the whole thing was so well-preserved. Looking out the window, I kept wanting everything to fade, and be back in the past (although really, that would be scary - from a merely practical view I mean - all those 16th century Spanish nuns!) Actually, what I really wanted to happen, which I couldn't convey properly to anybody there, since none of them had been in my Comparative Civs class, was for Peter Ustinov to come walking down the hall, talking to one of said 16th-century Nuns in English, while she answered him in Spanish, with subtitles. Lol, I think I watched entirely too many movies on the Vatican - I don't know what I'll do when I go to Rome! So anyway, we climbed up all the - very cool - stairs to the very top, where it opened onto the roof. I need some new words to replace "cool" and "neat", but it was both of those, in abundance, as well as sort of scary, when we climbed the rickety wooden ladder to the very top. If it hadn't been so bloody hot, it's exactly the sort of place I'd love to sit for hours and read my book.

Then we wandered some more, and looked at a museum, which was set up in the oldest building in Valladolid, a chapel which adjoined the old hospital (no longer intact). All the interpretations were in Spanish, but it was kind of fun to read it anyway. I could get the gist of most of it, even if I couldn't read it word for word. Long process, though.
In the afternoon (after lying in the hotel room panting for a while from the heat of it all) we drove out to Rio Legartos (probably spelled wrong..) where there were, purportedly, flamingos. Beautiful drive, through real (rural) Mexico - the cutest towns and churches along the way. Even if we hadn't seen the flamingoes, I would have enjoyed it just for the drive. I really do like travelling by car, whether as a passenger or driver. But we did get to see the flamingoes, albeit more by good luck then good management. Found a road and drove down it till we got to a beach - Gulf of Mexico this time. NOt astonishingly blue and clear like the Caribbean; more green, and siltier, but nice sand and good water to paddle one's feet in. On the way back, we came to bridge, where a man with a boat was just letting off a group of people who, for 300 pesos (30 bucks American, at the moment) he had taken to see the flamingos. Took us, too. Great boat ride, vast numbers of flamingoes, which are really rather foolish-looking birds, plus some really bizarre water which was quite literally pink - supposedly as a result of the salt crystals contained therein. We took some crystals back with us, plus a lot of pictures, 2 shells, and the skeleton (so to speak) of a horseshoe crab, which Mum has christened Dobbin. She's a funny duckling, my mother. 

Nice ride back, good meal, etc. The shower here's kinda funny. Actually, the whole place is rather odd - I suspect it caters rather more to Europeans than Americans...did I say that? Who knows. I thought it.
Oh, and I am in disgrace for neglecting to mention iguanas and monkeys in my previous entries. So consider them mentioned, lol. There were iguanas absolutely all over the little ruins we saw on Cozumel, including one fabulous orange one at the entrance, plus equally vast hordes all over this area. And at the Cenote we visited yesterday, there were monkeys everywhere, which were actually very cute. I loved the sign in the parking lot: "Please lock your car. Monkeys at play." No, seriously! And, "Do not bring food into the park. It will make the monkeys bite."
An interesting place, Mexico. And Chichen Itza tomorrow! Goodnight! :)

Friday, March 7th/03
And even in Mexico they have smiling teeth holding toothbrushes...
Didn't write last night because of a nmber of things - mainly an hour spent on the (amazingly slow) Internet, combined with an irresistable urge to read my book. Aong with pressure from external sources to go to bed early.
I'm thinking there won't be much chance to write tonight, either. Most likely, a proper entry will have to wait until we're in Los Angeles tomorrow.
But a brief update, at any rate...

Well, we've certainly gone down in the world. From the Presidente Intercontinental to a quite decent but somewhat European hotel in Valladolid to this...a $25 cabana on a beach in the Carribbean. Electricity from 6 till 11:30 nightly, hammocks, mosquite netting, a fan (which goes off with the electricity, of course), and interesting critters in the bathroom. But it's cute and authentic and has fresh-squeezed orange-juice, fresh-fried tortilla chips, and a lovely walk to a lovely beach with lovely waves and unabashed skinny-dippers. I suspect that laws governing such things are somewhat looser in Mexico, but no-one would dream of doing that at El Presidente. Hang-ups are funny things, aren't they? And that one in particular - about bodies, I mean. I suppose I'm subject to it too, from a personal point of view, but I certainly have no problem with other people being naked. It's lik, we all know what we look like anyway, for Heaven's sake, so what on Earth is the problem? It's all that retroactive Puritanism, I suppose...

Chichen Itza yesterday and Tulum today. Both fascinating, in different ways. Chichen Itza was the more impressive site in a number of respects. The thing I most appreciated about it was that there were buildings you were allowed to go inside. Not many of them, but enough to appease me. Such was not the case in Tulum, and it frustrated me to no end. I mean, I can understand their wanting to preserve the buildings, but it's so frustrating to have to read about the carvings etc onthe insdie and not be able to see any of it. It's enough to make a person aspire to be an archeologist!

Pressure to be finished...I'll write tomorrow.
G'night. :)

Saturday, March 8th/03
So it's tomorrow. We're in the "restaurant" at this "hotel". It's absolutely without exception the slowest service I have ever witnessed anywhere. I can understand with the orange juice since it is quite literally fresh-squeezed, but how long does it take to make an omelet?
Anyway. We've now spent our last night in Mexico, which was quite pleasant until 11:30, when the fan went off. Then it was hot. Plus there was a spring in the middle of my mattress. But that's okay - it was only one night. Sorry about the messiness of this writing, btw, but it's astoundingly windy here.

So where was I? Ruins! It's amazing how well-preserved the ones at Chichen Itza are, compared ot the other ones we've seen, especially since they're the oldest of the bunch. I guess it's because they're the furthest inland, so they don't get eroded by salt and wind and water as much. There are two parts of Chichen Itza - the older part, which dates from the 5th century (1600 years!) almost impressed me more than the new part, which was constructed mainly in the Late and Terminal Classic Periods. There were lots of carvings still very clear on all of the buildings, and even colour on a number of them - at one point, of course, all of the buildings were brilliantly painted, but now mainly all that's left is touches of red. 
The Castilla, the gigantic temple which is the one everyone associated with Chichen Itza and the Maya, was certainly very impressive, and you could climb it, which made it even better. How much of a lesson in history and archaeology and architecture do you want? Each of the four sidews has 91 steps set at a 45 degree slope (very steep to climb!). The entire temple is constructed to represent the Mayan calendar cycle, and is oriented in such a way that at the Equinox the light hits it just right and forms the image of a serpent ascending or descending the building. It's actually built on top of another older temple pyramid, which you can go in and see, but I didn't because it was really hot and supposedly quite claustrophic in there. There's another building in the more recent part of Chichen Itza with a unique design feature related to solar events as wel...

...I'm going to finish this on the plane or in LA, I think, since I need to pack and this might take awhile...

Still Saturday...11pm LA, 1am body time
Might as well start writing while I wait my turn for the shower...
We would run out of sunscreen on the last day, of course. Mum claims there would have been enough to do my back and arms if I'd wanted it, but I know smfo, as it were. Today I got thoroughly sunburnt, replugged my ear, and spent the rest of the day in airports and airplanes. Then we got to LA and waited for the shuttle, and then our room wasn't made up, so we waited for them to get us a new one. And now here we are. All in all it's been an eventful day. And I truly, officially, despise my sinuses. I almost cried when my ear blocked up again - would have, if we hadn't been in a public place. It's absolutely the most frustrating experience I've ever had - and I thought it was over, and now here we are again. I hate this.
And I feel like a tomato. My own fault, I know. Didn't feel like getting into and out of a damp, sandy, salty bathing suit this morning when we went "wave-jumping", so I just swam in my bra and underwear. Both black, it worked well. And on that beach, I was by no means underdressed for the occasion. The majority of the women, in fact, were topless, and a number of people of both sexes were bottomless as well. Nevertheless, I felt most peculiar parading about the beach in my underwear - I know it's just like a bikini, but I'm so modest to begin with...it was weird, and it was almost weirder cause it wasn't that weird. Never mind. That's how I got sunburnt, anyhow. Walking down the beach for an hour in my underwear, with no sunscreen except on my shoulders and my nose.

So, ruins .Ever more with the ruins. I'm tired of talking about Chichen Itza - if you want to know more, buy a book or visit.
...Actually, it's shower time and bed...amazing how after automatically reaching for the tap to brush my teeth every single day in Mexico, today I looked around for a cup and a bottle of water...in Los Angeles...
Tomorrow, tomorrow, the constant refrain. G'night! :)

Friday, February 27th/03
And just a wee bit pinker around the edges...despite my best intentions, my nose insists on displaying signs of redness. My ear is stuffed up, too, and driving me nuts. I hate not being able to hear!

Hmm...and what "witty observations" have I to share with you tonight? Fewer than last night, I suspect, but we shall see...
DAMP! It is the only word for this place! Everything everywhere is damp - you just can't avoid it. All our books are warping, all our clothing - not just the bathing suits - feel s like we went swimming in it the day before and didn't let it air properly. It's been very good for my face and lips, though, I'll give it that. I've been having trouble with chapped lips in particular for months while we've gone through this dry winter. Here, I don't even need chapstick!

Lowell's not at all well. The rest of us went on a glass-bottom boat to go snorkelling this morning, and he stayed int he hotel room and watched cartoons. He hasn't really eaten in three days. It's not good. I , on the other hand, have wound up eating entirely too much. I'm not used to this three-meals-a-day thing, and restaurant portions are huge. We've only been travelling four days, and I've had my fill (so to speak - no pun intended) of restaurants! Urgh.

The snorkelling was cool. I didn't see anything particularly exciting (Dad saw eels and sting rays) , but there were some very beautiful fish. Our guide, Alex (who kept hitting on me) brought tortillas into the water to feed them, and they would cluster all around your face so that you could practically touch them. It was the oddest experience.
Other than that, we didn't do much today. Mum had classes, Lowell was sick and Dad was reading/snorkellin, so I "practiced my piano" on a ledge outside our room. It's actually probably really good for forcing my memory on some of the songs - the Bach, for example - cause it's impossible to run on automatic pilot. For the Debussy, however, playing a table is all but useless - the point is the atmosphere, not the notes. I had a towel on the ledge to protect my hands, but playing Cat and Mouse hurt my fingertips nevertheless, and I had to be in a fairly awkward position to play at all. I think I'm going to try to find a wide table or something tomorrow.

The other thing I did this afternoon was to finish my book - I've been reading Wutherin gHeights, cause I'd always meant to, and in Lit Class we get credit for it. I have read few novels, however, that were as grim in scope as this one. Each character more tragic than the last, so that you couldn't help pitying - and yet, somehow, despising - each one of the sorry lot. Pracitcally everyone died at a young age, usually of consumption, after having lived a terrble, abused life. It only really worked out well for  three characters, minus the narrator, who wasn't really involved at all. Nevertheless, it was an interesting and well-written story. I am glad I read it - I just need something a bit more cheery to continue. 

We ate dinner otnight in the oldeste restaurant on Cozumel - Casa Denis's. On the way back to the hotel (actually, this was last night, but I thought about it again on the way back tonight),Lowell pointed out the lighthouse, and said he'd never seen one before. I was appalled - he was born in Fredericton after all! And he said yes but he was little, on which point I had to concur. The point of this anecdot, however, comes from my thinking how funny it is how our associations with things can linger on long after recollections of the events themselves have passed into obscurity. I remarked to Mum that, for no particular reason, I associated that lighthouse (in Fredericton, I mean) with a ball pit. (Assuming no actual link.) And she replied that that made perfect sense, since there was a ballpit in that lighthouse and once when Nana and Papa visited I had been allowed in it! Funny things, brains...
Heavy pressure to wrap this off so Mum can turn out the light. Tomorrow: honeymoons!
Gnight Kitty. Buenos Noches. :)

Saturday, February 28th/03
Major Mardi Gras celebrations tonight (parade, among other things) in San Miguel, which we studiously avoided. Call me a stick-in-the-mud, but I hate huge, noisy crowds of people. In the right mood, I wouldn't have minded it, but I've been sick all day and that would not  have been fun.
My ear (the right one) is driving me crazy. I woke up at 4 o'clock this morning and it was completely plugged, and I couldn't unplug it. That's SUCH an awful feeling; I don't think I've ever experienced it before - like having your nose really plugged and being unable to blow it, and thus unable to breathe. Only instead, I was prevented from hearing. I could feel the clogged up passage running all through my head. I seriously wanted to cry in desperation. Finally went back to sleep, but it was the same when I woke up this morning. Took antihistamines etc (you can buy Penicillin over the counter here!! and various other antibiotics...) but it persisted most of the day. It's slightly better now...it unclogged a bit during supper, to my intense relief...but still nothing like normal. On top of which, of course, I had to spend the whole day half-asleep because of the medication. And I've decided I definately never want to go deaf!

So, aside from being sick, what did I do today? We cancelled the horse-back riding thing cause Lowell was still ill (although he's getting better). Oh! We went to the Museum in the town. Very cool, but the high point was definitely (and patheitcally, I know) being able to get to a computer with Internet! And - wonder of wonders - Tyler was online! At 3pm on a Saturday afternoon! I didn't ask why...one doesn't question miracles. But it was amazing. I talked to him for about 20 minutes...which, in and of itself, was something of an adventure, since the keyboard was in Spanish! The letter keys were all in the right places, but the punctuation was all screwed up, and there were upside-down ?'s and n's with squiggles and stuff on there as normal keys. It was really bizarre - but so nice to talk to him, even if we had hardly any time. Plus he promised to email me, which is something to look forward to. :)

We ate supper at yet another cute little Mexican restaurant. I've decided I'm definately not cut out for eating meals. I'm a grazer - I do much better with small quantities of food frequently than I do with two or three large meals. I get full so quickly...this evening when we had dinner, I hadn't eater anything all day and I was really hungry, but I still couldn't finish my meal, and it wasn't even that big as restaurant meals go. I don't know what I'd do if I had to eat at restaurants all the time.

And honeymoons. This place makes me want to go on one. It makes me want to be married, just so I could go to a resort with my husband. They do these really cute candle-lit dinners, private ont eh beach for couples, with a guy serenading them and everything. Personally, that part of it kind of weirds me out - you're tyring to have a romantic candle-lit dinner and there's this strange guy 3 feet away singing at you!! - but the whole thing...I dunno. I guess I must be a romantic at heart. Or else I'm just a teenager. Take your pick.

Tomorrow Mum doesn't have any courses, so we've rented a car and we're going to drive around Cozumel and see the local ruins, and botanical gardens, and what-have-you. I intend to be better. So does Lowell.
Buenos Noches, Kitty. :)

Sunday, March 2nd ( I screwed up the dates...)
It's only 10 o'clock, but they want to go to sleep. I expect this entry will have to be brief...
...Hunh. Which I guess is okay, since I seem to be braindead anyway. What on Earth did we do today? Hmm... well, we took the rental car, and first we went along the coast to a park called Chankanaab. Cost more than it was worth to get in, but there was some cool stuff. Some recovered ruins from various sites in the Yucatan were there, along a little path through the jungle. I wished I'd brought my camera. It was interesting in particular to see the difference in style between the stelae and statues of the Mayans and those of the Olmec, Toltec, and Oaxacan peoples, which were also on display. There were also some submerged artifacts off the coast which you could see when you went snorkelling...artificially submerged, I suspect, but cool nonetheless. 

After that, we did what, for me, has easily been the coolest part of this trip so far - we visited our first official ruins! I think the site is caled San Gervasio, and it was the major Mayan city on Cozumel in the Classic and Postclassic PEriods of their civilization (AD 900-1500, mostly, with some earlier stuff - the Classic Period offically starts AD250.) Considering the age, it's absolutely amazing how much of the buildings and walkways have survived, especially considering they're constructed of limestone. I absolutely love stuff like that...ruins of old buildings that give you glimpses into an ancient time. Like historic villages (I mean, like pioneer villages) only more so. I think you have to have a vivid imagination in order to truly appreciate that stuff - you have to (at least, I have to) be able to recreate in my head what it was at the height of its glory. A story, but with visual aids. Some people suck at that, but I've done it forever. 
Even if you can't do that, though, you still have to admire that stuff from the sheerly archaeological point of view. And architectural - the architectural works they accomplished without benefit of any modern technology is extraordinary - that's a helluva lot of slave labour!

Drove around the Island (quite literally AROUND the permieter) this afternoon. Serious waves on the beaches on the Caribbean side - I've never seen such extraordinary surf! Dinner another adventure, and with the aid of a Q-tip my ear FINALLY popped properly (this morning it was clogged up again), so now all that is required is for Lowell to get better.
Bowing to familial pressure and turning off the lights... 'Night, Kits. :)

03/03/03!! Monday, March 3, 2003.
Listening to Moxy Fruvous...gimme a couple minutes; the CD's almost over (I think)...I really have to buy a couple of their albums - I've downloaded about 50 of their songs and I feel very guilty...wow, this CD just keeps going...Splatter Splatter maintenant...ah, and Stuck in the 90's - this is a really good CD!

Lol I'm all sore today from piggy-backing Lowell yesterday when he was tired at the ruins. I carried him about 300 metres, and now I'm paying for it. He's only about 30 lbs lighter than me, so it's quite a feat. Makes me appreciate Tyler, lol...he insisted on piggy-backing me at the Cannery when we were in Rupert last, despite my protests. Silly boy - still, it was his own fault. And Tyler's got more to him than it looks like. He looks like maybe 160 pounds, and he weighs closer to 180. Go figure.
...Down From Above; I was wondering if we'd get to it...

Had quite a nice day today, without really doing much of anything Mum and I (an dLowell, sort of) built a sandcastle this morning, with the help/hindrance of a very loquacious (sp?) two-year-old named Julia (as she told us many times) and her mother, Carolyn. Snorkelled for while, but I don't like the way it makes my ears feel, plus my contacts get dry, so mostly I lay in the sun and read my book. 
I'm reading The Sparrow, which is an absolutely awesome book by Mary Doria russell, whom I've never heard of before. Mum told me to read it, and as usual she's right - I love it. The dialogue's wonderful, and the characterization is superb. They feel like real people. It was funny, I was down on the beach, reading, and I looked up and there was aguy sitting on the next chair over reading the same book. Then he looked up too, and we laughed and agreed that it was excellent, and went back to our respective novels.

Lowell's still sick, poor child. That really sucks, to come to Mexico and feel lik e shit. Especially when you're in Grade 7 and it's easy to miss 2 weeks of school to be sick some other time. They've bought him some Ammoxyl (over the counter, lol) and we're hoping it's bacterial and he'll start feeling better.
We're leaving here tomorrow and going to the mainland. Not sure where we're staying tomorrow night - either Valladolid or some place that starts with a T that I can't remember the name of. I want to get up early tomorrow to take pictures of bird tracks in the sand before they get trampled over, plus I want to read more tonight, plus I have nothing else in particular to say, so I'll leave it at that.

Mexico's nice, but sometimes it's hard not to miss home. Or at least, the people. :) Goodnight, Kitty. :)

Wednesday, February 26th/03

This place is nuts! It's so...so resort-y. Well, it IS a resort. It's wierd. I'm not used to this. Our room opens right onto the beach, which reminds me intensely of the Cabana in Monkey Island III. It looks exactly like that.
I'm no good at this Spanish thing. It's the strangest thing, but I keep wanting to speak in French. It's like, I know a foreign language is required, and the one my mouth automatically goes for is French. I have to quell the urge to say "Je m'excuse" when walking through a crowd, and "Merci" when I'm served. "Gracias" just doesn't roll off my tongue quite the same. 'S funny, though, I can understand the gist of Spanish pretty well, if it's spoken slowly. Dad's got pretty passable Spanish, and when he was talking to the taxi driver on the way over here, I understood most of their conversation - including the part where he asked whether our fish (in Canada) were ocean or fresh water!

The steward who gave us our meals (almost-edible pasta) on the plane over here asked where we were from. "Canada," I replied, and he said, "Well, that explains it then. American kids never say thank-you." 

Gawd, but Cancun was awful. There are few things I hate more than those pushy tour people. I mean, I know it's only their job, but we couldn't walk five steps through that airport without being accosted by someone else wanting to sell us things. And then Playa del Carmen, which is a tourist trap if I ever saw one, but cute nonetheless. Full of tiny, perfect, absurdly-priced pseudo-ethnic shops. Adorable.
And now Cozumel, a little island off the east coast of Mexico. Several thousand kilometres, two countries, two days, and a coast away from hom, but you can still see Orion. That reassures me, somehow. It makes me still feel connected to Northwest British Columbia in some small way. I love stars.

Oh, and I discovered that its practically impossible - almost painful, really - for me to watch other people work. Lowell's come down sick (he's got a fever and is looking quite peaked) so I decided that instead of sharing a bed with him at the risk of contracting his illness (just as I'm getting over my own, of course), I would request a cot bed, and sleep in that. So it came, accompanied by the Ubiquitous Busboy. Who proceeded to set it up.
It drove me nuts! Not that he needed help - actually, I could only have hindered him, he was miraculously efficient - but it was still so difficult not to offer, to just sit there and let him do all the work. I almost had to leave the room...and would have, if the process hadn't been so fascinating to watch. I have never in my life before seen a bed made so incredibly efficiently. It was awe-inspiring.

Tomorrow Mum has classes, and we are free to bask in the sun or do as we please - the beach here is absolutely gorgieous (that word again). In the afternoon I believe the paln is to go to the town on this island (where the ferry lands - I can't remember the name off-hand) and reconnoiter. I suspect they're looking for someplace less staggering to buy food.
...There is, of course, the mandatory MacDonalds...

'Night, Kitty. :0 I'll write further tomorrow.

Thursday, February 26th/ 03
Only mildly sunburned...
The beach is beautiful, though I've never been big on salt water in general. The deck chairs are beautiful. The pool is beautiful. The fish are beautiful. I think I may have to break downa nd buy a bikini in San Miguel (that's the name of the town on the island). Practically everyone here has them, and lots of those women have less attractive bodies than I...besides, when you're lying on your back in the sun, what does it matter?

This afternoon we went into town. Quite nice, once we got off the main drag, but the touristy part was awful. Each of the vendors trying to outyell his opponents to get your attention. Funny, cause, in my case anyway, they accomplish basically the opposite of their goal...I steer clear even of shops I would normally go into and browse, just because I'm afraid of being accosted. A shame, there was some cute stuff...
The residential areas of the town were fascinating, however. The courtyards of the houses are so cool! It's like a different world... We saw bougainvillea over some of the walls, which made me think of "The Pearl" by John Steinbeck. (Bougainvillea was one of our vocabulary words when we did that novel in English in Grade 9.) the coolest buildings, though, I thought, were the abandoned ones. Old abandoned buildings always fascinate me. I can't but wonder at their history. 
We ate dinner at an adorable Mexican-Argentinean restaurant...I don't know the name of it, but it's owned by the same family that owns the oldest restaurant on Cozumel - since 1945. The waiter (a grandson of the family) was very talkative. Another 'small world' story - he has a good friend from Prince Rupert! It was the strangest thing...

Spanish is an interesting thing. I know it isn't surprising and it shouldn't surprise me, but I can't help being amazed at the similarities to English and French - particularly the latter. I mean, there's lots of words that are common to English, but wow - if you know French, you ca figure out practically anything written in Spanish, if you have the sense to pay attention to both context and linguistic similarities. It's so cool!

They don't have a piano here. I'm going to go nuts - not practice for 2 weeks?! I mean, I can make do with stretches and stuff, but really, there's only so much you can do with a table. Oh well. I mean, I guess I'll survive...I sort of have to.
I think I dream more when I'm away from home. In LA I dreamt what was, biarrely, quite a scary dream, which more than anything was about the computer game Master of Orion, which I haven't even looked at, let alone played, in about four years. Last night was a much pleasanter dream. 'S funny, I don't dream about Tyler very much at all - I rarely have romantic/sexual dreams anyway, but when I do I hardly ever know the other person, and extremely rarely do I actually have dreams about my current crush (or, in this case, boyfriend!) This was a harmless dream...all I remember was holding Tyler...just holding him and being helf and wanting never to let go. A pleasant way to spend the night, lol.

Tomorrow morning we're going on a glsas-bottom boat ride, and snorkelling and stuff. I hope to be able to find an Internet Cafe as well, at some point. I think there's one at the Museum my mum wants to visit.
It's SO humid here! Everything's damp - even this book is getting warped around the edges, and it hasn't been anywhere near water!

G'night, Kitty. :) Sweet dreams. :)

Tuesday, February 25th
Enroute over the United States maintenant..., Vancouver to Los Angeles on our way to Cozumel, Mexico via Cancun. We have a stop-over tonight in LA - I've never been there before - it should be an interesting city to land in, cause it's so big. 
We're in Cozumel for a week, cause Mum's got this conference thing (continuing education, or whatever), and then we're going to travel some and look at Mayan ruins and the like. Now that we're actually on our way, I'm almost excited - I haven't been yet; I've been too busy being stressed. Have you any idea how difficult it is to miss 2 weeks of grade 12 courses?! I'm oing to have a lot of work to catch up on! Plus, I'm not sure how I'm going to practice, and if I have to go two weeks without practicing right before Festival, it's gonna KILL my fingers! Nevertheless, we're going to Mexico, and I'm determined to have fun. :)

Went to Rupert with Katy last weekend (Friday was a Non-Instructional Day) to see Martina and Tyler. I think she had fun, even though she's an expert at convincing herself otherwise, particularly in retrospect. I'm not sure why she does that, but it's similar to her attitudes owards practically everything. It's like she's determined not to enjoy herself.
At anyrate, it was mostly fun. We went to Brad's (the milkshake place) and then walked along the railroad tracks at the Cannery. It was a nice day in Rupert, for once, so we went exploring, and found the most adorable rocks along the water - perfect for sitting for hours and reading. Katy and I decided that at some point we'll have to do that.
In terms of Tyler, nothing changed much visibly. He was...touchy-er, but then, he's been getting progressively that way for weeks now. It's nice. :) Katy says I changed...she says I was more...well, "aggressive" was the word she used, but I'm not sure it's the right one. I initiated more, and reciprocated more, is what she meant. I didn't notice it, but that's probably true, and it makes sense. As she pointed out, I definately know he likes me now, so I don't need to be worried about how I'm "supposed" to act.
I think the funniest thing about the whole situation, though, is our parents, and particularly our mothers' very disparate reactions. My mother clearly doesn't care what we do (yes, that's what I mean) so long as I don't wind up in trouble (read: pregnant.) Tyler's mother, on the other hand, is adament about the abstinence thing, almost to the point of absurdity. We're not allowed to sleep in the same room when we're at his house - which, of course, is blatantly ridiculous a) because we sleep in the same bed when we're at MY house, and b) because if we anted to have sex it's silly to think that not being permitted to sleep int he same room would have any effect as a deterent, since very little sleep is actually involved. Nevertheless, one follows the rules. :) And it's not like she's not pleased about us going out. From the number of times she managed to slip the words "my son's girlfriend" into conversations while we were there, I'd say she very happy with the turn of events. It's just that Ellen Lieb would like me to marry (yes; that dreaded word) her son...whereas my own mother's attitude towards that hallowed institution is more along the lines of, "Whatever you do, don't..." An interesting predicament. But fear not...I have no plans to marry anyone at all for a number of years yet. :P
More later...

Nine in the evening...
Apologies at the outset for what I fear may prove to be the rather irritating, condescending tone of this entry. I have discovered (from reading Pride and Prejudice last spring, if you will recall), that when I spend any great length of time reading Victorian novels, I inevitably begin adopting a similar method of speech. Well, otday I have read fully a third of Wuthering Heights, and no doubt my writing will be coloured accordingly. Apologies.
On the flight to Los Angeles, there was, accompanying us, a group of highschool students. I presume they were involved in a school travel club of some description - at any rate, they were talking of passports, and LA was not their final destination. I realized how much I truly detest teenagers. REally, it's incredibly unreasonable of me, particularly since I myself belong to that class. Obviously I like some teenagers (like, pretty much all the ones at my school that I know at all, plus certain Rupertites) - but teenagers, when in groups and when you don't know the individuals concerned, are rather repulsive creatures. It's certainly no fun travelling on a plane with them unless you're one of them - and even then it can be embarassing!
This city is huge! Yes, yes, I know, understatement of the year, but seriously! BIG! A very nice man who works at the hotel (he looks like Morgan Freeman) recommended us to a restaurant and got us a free shuttle lift there. An Italian restaurant called Italy's Little Kitchen - somewhat expensive, but good food, and absolutely adorable.

I miss Tyler. I know that's sad, but I do. And not even because we're 10 000 miles away, either (although that too), but just on general principles. I want to have him HERE - it's most annoying. (This is the part where I skim over the rest of the entry while relaying it to Katy, cause from here on in it's useless gushing that you only need to read if you're an incurable romantic or a glutton for punishment.)
It's funny how much more you miss somebody when you know the feelings are reciprocated - that is, when you know that they miss you, too. It's the most perverse thing, but Tyler's been complaining and complaining about me leaving - saying he's gonna go nuts and email me every day and all that (which he DID do when I was in Vancouver, by the way)...and somehow I forgot to say I'd miss him too. I was the one who pushed this relationship, who fundamentally caused it, I suppose...and yet he's the one falling over himself with displays of affection and I find it difficult, somehow, to do likewise - not cause I don't want to, not cause I don't feel it, but, well...well, I'm not really sure why. It's bizarre. {[The history of our relationship and fully 1/3 of the problems leading to its dissolution, stated offhand and unconcernedly less than two weeks after we started going out. Wow.]}
But when it comes to affection, to romantic affection, I'm a wonderful recipient. I'm like a starved child. I take absolutely nothing for granted - I relish every moment in his presence, and my heart quite literally quickens at his every touch. Still. Maybe that's parthetic, but I've gone so long assuming that no one cared about me that way, it's like a miracle every second. [[Oh, absolute selfishness..you and I are clearly destined for greatness.]] Sometime last week I realized I could touch too, I could initiate, I could give that back, and that was another miracle. This weekend was tantalizing and yet incredibly unsatisfactory, because we had so little time alone - since we weren't permitted to sleep together - and it just gave me glimpses and left me wanting, so much more. I don't mean sex. I honestly don't care much about that either way, and if it happens and some point I have no particular moral aversions to that, but neither do I have any particular desire to cause that situation. I just mean...Being. Together. Comfort, if such a thing makes any sense in that context. I always feel unfulfilled and somewhat cheated on weekends when I see Tyler and don't get to spend the night with him - this time its worse, because it will be fully three weeks - til Spring Break - before I see him again, and I'm so far away... And there was a quality to it this weekend that made it even more painful to leave than before. As I said, nothing in particular changed, physically, but there was a quality to it, of intimacy, I suppose, that strengthened, and is so very tantalizing. Untangible, but there, and so hard to leave willfully. 
At any rate. I digress. As usual. At times, in fact, this journal strikes me as simply one long digression...
Tomorro wmorning we fly to Cancun, and from there we have a bus ride and ferry to Cozumel and warm sandy beaches.

Until Mexico! A lovestruck Caitlin. :)

This one's a long-haul, sorry. I wanted to get everything pre-Mexico (read: severe Tyler drama) out of the way in one go, and there was no good place to split it up...but it's a LOT of stuff. Be prepared. :)

Saturday, Feb 1st/03

Brief update (I am, as usual, massively tired) on the State of the Universe before I go to sleep.
First: Tests. Since I relied at least partially on your influence to get me through, I figure you deserve to know how they went. The Bio one (Thursday morning) was great - one of the easiest I looked at out of all those practice provincials we did. The last question was the worst, probably; it focussed on LH & FSH in the Ovarian cycle - something I've never been able to keep straight. But, easy.
The Physics one, however, was really hard. Like, probably harder than every one of the past ones we did. However, Mr Wootton thought it was really hard too, and he wrote a letter to Victoria about it - which probably means the marks will get bumped up, since he's very influential - probably the most respected Physics teacher in the province. Seriously, UBC offers him cars and houses and exorbitant amounts of money every year to work there - but for some reason he loves Terrace, and he loves highschool phsyics. Which is wonderful for us!!
CCN was easy - more so than I suspected. Probably lost a maximum of 6 marks total, out of 120. Thanks. :)

Tuna's up this weekend, so we've been "doing stuff". It's so bizarre to have no homework! This evening we went to the performance at the REMLee of the Vagina Monologues. It was packed! And very interesting - funny/poignant. I'd expected it to be very uncomfortable, but it wasn't. My mother's friend Karla Hennig played a lesbian dominatrix. She was hilarious, but I felt SO sorry for Alex, her 12-year-old son (Lowell's friend) who was in the audience. Watching you rmother fake an orgasm on stage in a teddy in front of 700 people - talk about mortifying!
Anyways, it's been. [[?]] Got a couple of Tshirts from Warehouse 1 yesterday - "I say bad words", and "Don't Mess With Me, or my Angels will kick your Ass." Cute.
And now it is time to sleep...G'night. :)

Sunday, February 9th, 2003
It's funny, isn't it, how things we've been anticipating for ages happen right when you least expect them. When I was ten, I spent one night (shortly after I'd been given a book on "Your Body and You") absolutely convinced I was going to get my period that very night. I must have gone to the washroom every 20 minutes for 5 hours. I know I didn't sleep. When I finally did get my period, a couple of months later on the day before my eleventh birthday, we were in Alabama, of all places, I was entirely unprepared, and it took me completely by surprise. Go figure.
I guess I stopped waiting, or hoping, or expecting - you pick an appropriate verb - for him to kiss me a couple of months ago. I realized it was silly; he's expressed no interest in a romantic relationship with me, and so far I'd dragged the relationship we did have every step of the way. Why on earth should he initiate that, when he'd initiated nothing else? And naturally I wasn't going to kiss him - if you knew me at all you'd realize the idea is ludicrous - therefore it clearly wasn't going to happen. C'est la vie. End of story.
Last night after the Todd Butler concert (great satirist, phenomenal guitarist), Tyler and Katy and I watched What Dreams May Come in my bedroom. Well, Katy wasn't really watching it; mainly she was just sleeping on my floor. She's seen it before, and basically she just wanted an excuse not to go home. Tyler hadn't seen it before and I wanted him to - it's a wonderful film - so we lay in the bed and watched it.
I love watching movies when you've someone to intertwine yourself with - it's a novel experience, and I love it. I love cuddling - the security of having someone else there with you. Scary movies in particular are nicer if you've got a reassuring presence beside you. And I love the subtle, gentle finger-flirting that happens during movies. Just touches of fingers, moving, stroking, feather-soft. The awareness of two people of each other.
Last night he was very cuddly. Holding and petting and awareness. It's so funny, that awareness on two levels. Complete attention is being paid to the movie - and yet at the same time you're entirely focused on the person besdie you. What Dreams May Come is not a scary movie. It's beautiful. And it's romantic.
Romantic movies are dangerous. At least, they are for Tyler. It must have done something to him, or maybe it was just the time of night and the situation, but he's never been so totally on that secondary level before. We were utterly aware of each other, and by the time the movie finished there was this astounding, profound, unspoken tension between us. He got up to turn off the movie and came back and it was still there, that amazingly physical tension. I could feel it like an ache, everywhere in my body. I could feel it in him too, in the oddness of his breathing.
I apologize if this is too frank for you, but I need an outlet. Feel free to skim if its too uncomfortable. At any rate, we just lay there for nearly ten minutes, unable to do anything but let it flow through us like a circuit. Holding on, just holding on. Touching in too many places, and not nearly enough. And I don't know if he meant to or not, but he kissed me. Just leaned over, and it was dark and I didn't notice and then his mouth was on my mouth and his tongue and...well, I've never been kissed before, but I must have a fiarly accurate sub-conscious because it felt just like in dreams except it was real, and he was real.
We were quiet for a long time afterwards, and I don't know if my breathing sounded like his, but his was jagged, like moving across a rippled surface. I didn't know what I was supposed to say, if anything - I think I was in shock. And I didn't particularly want him to say anything - nothing I could think of would be right.
What he finally said was, "I've never been that nervous about kissing a girl before. That was really odd." I still couldn't say anything - what should I say? Then he half-laughed and said, "Well, your mum will be pleased, anyway," which is ironically true. And all I could think of was my mother's not-really-joking comments about birth control a few weeks ago, and how quickly things change. We both have excellent self-control, but we still had to separate completely (40 minutes later), before we could calm down enough to sleep. And what if we weren't us, and what if we had alcohol in our systems? Don't mistake me - we were never in any danger of having sex in my waterbed with my best friend on the floor besdie us, my 12-year-old brother above us, and my parents in the next room. But that tension - it was so tangible.
*Lol*, that was the other thing he said that night, before we moved on: "I'm a sucker for romantic movies...obviously." And, "If we had been fighting with real swords, you would have killed me." 
And now I've joined the ranks of the Been Kissed. It's so bizarre. I've been completely, pathetically useless all day. Things have only ever hit me so off kilter three times before - when I found out Travis liked me; when Travis asked me out; and whne Tyler sent me that melody/harmony email. Guys have a funny way of screwing with my internal organs. They all feel turned around and upside down. But for now...this beats 'em all.
And I was completely unsuspecting.
Go figure. 'Night, Kitty love. :)

...And still, it sounds like a story. It sounds like someone else. Why can't I make it sound like us.
All I can say is, for someone who wants a solely platonic relationship, he has a funny way of expressing his convictions.
Caitlin.

Tuesday, February 11th/03
I'm hesitant to begin writing, because inevitably when I get out my journal on an airplane, the intercom immediately comes on to say we've begun our descent and blah blah blah. Perhaps today will be different. We shall see.
In case you didn't know, I'm going to Vancouver for this Honour Choir thing. I have to billet (EEK!), and I'm coming home Sunday. This is, I realized, the first time I've travelled by myself on an airplane without being a severely over-coddled Unaccompanied Minor. (Let us not even get into THAT experience!) It's kinda cool, but I'm terrified of billeting. I've only done it once (Grade 10 band trip), and it was a scary experience. I'm not good at strangers. Oh well.

*Sigh* I think Tyler's losing his battle. We had a very odd conversation last night on MSN - he kept almost bringing things up, and then saying "Never mind." One of the oddest things he said was, "You realize, of course, that the cards have changed hands...", which threw me off. The only thing I can think he was referring to was a pervious comment of mine (in an email) that he "held all the aces". But what happened, then? I'm not sure why, or if there even is a why, precisely, but it sounds to me like he's falling... He was gentle and sweet and confused - he signed off with "'Night, love." Love is an extraordinarily direct word... he was shocked to learn I was leaving today - I thought he knew, but I guess not. He asked if I would email, and I said I wasn't sure I'd have the facilities available, but that he could always *gasp* email me. (!!) He said he would - every day. I said no offense, but I'd believe that when I saw it. If he writes me one email while I'm gone I'll be impressed. 
It's funny how we switch back and forth being the romantic one. Last night, he was very sweet. He was talking the way he acts when he's being cuddly - his words were cuddly, they felt like he was wrapping his arms around me from behind and pulling me back against him, and nestling his chin in my hair. And somehow, the more he got like that, the more I couldn't - I felt compelled to keep my distance, to tease and feign misunderstanding. But it's gone the other way too, I've pushed it and leant against him, and although he's permitted it he was somehow unable to respond. I guess we spend a lot of time like that, taking turns being in love. And when we're both there at once, well... Saturday happens. It's massively powerful, and perhaps all the more so because for some reason it's rare.

We talked about prom - now there's a fraught subject. He brought it up Saturday night, after... oh, and there's the announcement - we'll talk about prom later I guess. :)

~11:39pm
Since I have to get up and pretend to be alive in less than seven hours, the clever thing to do would be sleep, but as we know...
Prom. On Saturday, Tyler said to me that he'd thought about asking me to his prom, but then realized that I would probably be miserable, and what did I think. I agreed that I probably would, and then he *asked me* if it was alright if he took someone else. To which I replied, "Well, of course!" It was sort of odd, like he felt he had an obligation to take me, which of course he doesn't. Kinda sweet of him to ask me though, anyway.
At any rate, we sorted that out, but I forgot to ask about my prom, which I'd been sort of meaning to bring up at a convenient time. So last night I asked him if he'd come to mine. He said, "Yeah, for sure," followed by, "although I find it funny you ask." I said, "What, as opposed to commanded?!" And he replied, "Well, yeah. I mean, you could have said 'You're taking me to prom!'" I said that really wouldn't be very well done of me, and he said, "Well, considering I basically asked to not take you to mine..." I said that it still wasn't done, but anyway it didn't matter, either way his answer was yes, and we left it at that.

"Yeah, for sure." I didn't really realize that the idea of prom was stressing me out until suddenly it wasn't any more. I think it's been bothering me, somewhere in the back of my mind, since around Grade 10, when I realized it was practically imminent. What if I didn't get asked to prom, what if no-one would take me, what if I had to go alone? These are legitimate concerns in a life such as mine, so devoid of meaningless romantic relationships. And, go figure, that too has sorted itself out. In what is almost the nick of time, I've become, for lack of a better turn of phrase, "romantically entangled". I will not graduate from highschool having never been kissed, and I will have someone to take me to my prom.

Still, the sorting-out concerns me slightly. My life has always had a way of doing that, of sorting itself out, of turning out for the best. And it's great - for me - but it's not really fair. Everything's almost always right and easy for me - why is it so hard for so many others? For some people nothing ever works out right. Why is that? Can we blame it on the stars? Was I born under a lucky one? That seems like a copout, but really, it's not fair. 
And this prom thing. I want to be ecstatic about it, this weight I didn't know about has been lifted from my shoulders - but is that fair, when Katy's still in that boat? She's studiously not letting that bother her - she's good at that - but I know it does, deep down. And I feel so unfair to be relieved of that burden while she still carries it, but it's notlike I can help her with it. I can't help her like someone, and I can't share Tyler with her, and giving him up would be useless...grrr, why does highschool have to be so fraught?

Thoroughly teenage smudges.
Oh, ps - My mother bought me condoms. She says she knows what I say, but she still prefers to trust her instincts.  ...her instincts are scary.... *L, 'night. :)

Wednesday, February 12th
...but quickly... 
She sets her clocks ahead too! And Tyler would love her - she owns "Kind of Blue", which is, according to Tyler, the definitive jazz album.
Her name's Roisin, pronounced Roy-Sheen. The other girl staying here is named Sharla, and she's from Salmon Arm. I have nothing in common with either of them. Of course. WHy is it that everyone but me seems to have things in common with most people? Why is it that I've always identified much more readily with adults than with people my own age? I mean, even the few people I do identify with are more people people (so to speak) than I am. I (obviously) get on very well with Tyler and with Katy...so how come they both seem so normal when I am clearly not.
At any rate. Trying not to write tangentially. Roisin and Sharla are both interesting characters, to put it mildly. Roisin strikes me as very much like everyone else. She looks popular, she likes popular stuff, she hangs out with other people who look popular. Sharla is Mormon, among other things. I get the distinct impression that she's extremely rightwing, and in particular extremely anti-gay. A shame, she seems like she could be an interesting girl. But very abrasive, and not at all hesitant to speak her mind.

The choir's wonderful. It's amazing. Words cannot describe the intense feeling of joy that comes from close harmonies and perfect silences in a resonant hall full of other people who take music seriously. And the guys, especially! Hearing them sing made me want to cry...
More tomorrow. Late and tired. Tyler wrote!! G'night. :)

Thursday, February 13th/03
It never rains but it pours. He lost his battle. 
This afternoon I got an email from Katy which consisted of one line: "Quick question, are you and Tyler going out?" Confused, I talked to her when she came online, and she said she'd been talking to Tyra, would been talking to Tyler, who told her that he'd kissed me and that we were (go figure!) going out. Hunh. New to me. Don't you love grapevinces? And Tyra had told Katy and Katy was naturally appalled to receive such information from anywhere other than its source, so she asked me about it. I told her that, if that was in fact that case, nobody had bothered to inform me. Oh, she also told Martina. (!!)
So I asked Tyler, also on MSN, what was going on. I said that I got an email from Katy, and that she'd been talking to Tyra.
He said, "Caitlin, would you go out with me?"
I said Yes. Of course.
He said *splash*.

So. Huh. It's sort of hard to register. We're going out. What does that mean? What does that change? I'm still not any clearer on this point than I was last February. (Travis - remember him?) Difference is, our relationship is already at a much more profound level to begin with. In certain respects we've moved past (or through) the steps of dating. On the other hand, we've kissed once. What happened there exactly? What changed his mind? When I asked him to define our relationship 2 months ago, he told me he wasn't interested in anything more than a platonic relationship. He told me he was too self-obsessed. And I haven't pushed it since then. I've reciprocated was he's given without saking for more.
These steps, he's taken. I always - well, for a few months - I've known he would go out with me if I asked him. I would never have done that, not because I'm shy or don't feel it's my place, but because I couldn't put him in that position. I wouldn't push him into anything unwilling. That's abuse of power, and I know he'd be miserable. I knew I had that power, but I let it sit. He knew my thoughts on the matter, so anytime he felt ready or comfortable to take those steps, he would be more than able.  ...To be honest, I'd sort of assumed that that meant we wouldn't go out, or at least not for months, not unless he changed drastically. Just like I didn't really believe he'd actually ever kiss me. I'm almost non-plussed. I'm in shock - again.
Tyler is my boyfriend. Officially. Try that on for size.. Somehow the transition makes perfect sense - somehow I've been saying that subvocally for months. So why is this such a shock, at the same time?
I've never done this before. I'm seventeen years old, and until last weekend I'd never kissed a guy. And until today I'd neever gone out with anyone.
Tyler asked me out.
That's one thing I love about human beings, their knack for stating and restating the utterly obvious.
Tomorrow is Valentine's Day. Tomorrow is also the choir concert. Tomorrow night, when I am full-up with choir instead of Tyler, I'll talk about that. Tonight, I'm busy being awestruck.
Somebody likes me. Someone wants to spend time with me exclusively. Moreover, this someone is someone that I liked first. This someone is someone fascinating. Someone I could spend a week with and not be bored for an instant.
My mother made this call two days ago. My mother is irritating. I should listen to my mother.
G'night. Wish me luck! :)

Thursday, January 2nd, 2003

Happy New Year!
...
I fell again. Hard and fast and it feels like I'm down for the count. I was doing so well..
I've just had an incredibly fun 3 days. It really did feel like summer all over again. Saturday and Sunday were entirely taken up constructing xmas presents for the Harem plus Tyler. (Oh gosh...I just had this horrible thought that you might not know what the Harem is. For future (and past) reference, Hans is our Master and Tyra, Cayley, Jessica, Martina, Katy, and I are his concubines - it happened over the summer...anyways...) We made summer baskets for everyone, and they were adorable! The highlights (that is, the parts that took the most time and cost the most) were a 2-CD Summer Music compilation, and a calendar made from summer pictures. That in particular cost way more than was our intention.
At any rate, they were fun to make and wonderful to give people. I truly love giving people gifts that they will honestly adore.

...*Sigh* I really want to write; I've got just oodles and oodles to say, but I'm sick and tired and have been staying up too late for days. I will talk more, but the upshot of New Years was that we adopted Andrew (Hans' step-brother) and I'm "in love", for lack of a better word, with Tyler again. Whole-heartedly. *sigh*.
So, later. G'night. :)

Sunday, January 19th/03
I'm not *really* writing...really, I'm going to sleep. But I just felt so guilty...
Lol, my whole bed smells like Tyler. Mmm. I love boy smell. :) (Gawd, I'm such a girl! It's terrible!) And on a related note...aren't parents amusing creatures? Here's today's entertaining anecdote:

Mum (drawing back from hugging me and looking at me with that half-serious half-mocking analytical way): Your father was wondering if maybe we needed to have another little talk with you about birth control...
I: *smirk*
M: Well, I told him that I thought you were pretty clear on the concept, and at any rate the point was probably moot...
I: Pretty clear on the concept, and any way, the point's moot.
M: Yes, well, just so you know. He said he thought the two of you seemed to be draping yourselves about each other more frequently than usual of late, and sometimes unexpected things can happen in the middle of the night, and it would really be a shame...
I: Clear on the concept. Point is moot.
M: He thought maybe we should buy you some condoms. You know, just in case...
I (resigned): *sigh* If it would make you feel better to buy me condoms, you go right ahead. Clear on concept. Point is moot. Clear on concept. Point is moot. Clear on concept. Point is moot.

I mean, like, WTF?! Gawd, we're not even GOING OUT! He's never even kissed me, or even shown any interest in doing so! But of course - OF COURSE - it makes perfect sense that despite this we will lose control of ourselves and have wild sex...on my waterbed...next door to my PARENTS' ROOM...hmm...does this conclusion seem potentially fallacious to anyone else?
But no. We're hormonal teenagers, after all. We can't help ourselves.
Obviously.
Yes, I know they don't mean anything by it and are just trying to be helpful, but Puh-LEASE! :p

'Tennyrate. Past my bed-time, as usual. There's your mini-rant for the night.
'Gnight. :)
Love Caitlin.

Friday, January 23rd
[Backwards] Getting "back" into the swing of things, haha...sorry. First item of gossip: David and Amy are going out! It's a testament to the infrequency of my updating that you didn't even know they liked each other. Goodness, this must be confusing. At any rate, they do, and they are. This would be normal except that, well, it's David. And David + girls = bad, as he himself has informed us on more than one occasion. He was such a hermit - and we broke him out of his shell. I'm not sure whether to feel jubilant or guilty. Maybe a little of both - "everything in moderation", right? 
Oh, and speaking of David, I decided I *ought* to have a crush on him. I don't - don't worry - but I ought to. He's perfect for me - just like Hans, and I couldn't like him either. Go figure. Instead I'm stuck with Tyler, lol. Who half-likes me. Whom I can only, for lack of a better word, describe as my not-boyfriend. It's one of those "definition" situations. We don't fit a mold. Actually, oddly enough, Tyler spent about half an hour one night a couple weeks ago being convinced that I had a crush on David - which (ironically) made him feel better, cause he has a crush on this girl, Charity, whom he met (once) at the New Year's Party...anyway.
Oh! and speaking of (post)adolescent relationships (which I believe we were), I've not yet told you about Chris Yeast...
Chris. He's cute, in a little boy, unibrowed sort of way. Actually, he's adorable. He reads - fontasy. He's a fun person. Altogether very good crush material - during Musical, Katy was looking, so I suggested him to her (jokingly). Trouble is, she's in danger of accidentally taking my advice and really liking him. She sees this as a problem...I don't, cause I see the potential in him to like her, too, and I think it would be good for her to be in a relationship - besides, then she can't get made at Tyler and me! :)
This is sketchy, but I'm getting tired. What else? Sons of Maxwell concert was tonight; it was awesome! They played "So Confusing", "The Lighthouse", AND "Queen of Old Argyle" (our absolute favourite) so we were very happy. 
Provincials next week...studying like mad...
G'Night. :)
